revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=October 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=October 2012}} }}
'''I Made Sidia''' is a [[Balinese people|Balinese]] [[wayang]] puppeteer. He is one of [[Bali]]'s most acclaimed shadow artists.
Graduated in 1992 with a degree in Balinese theatre (Pedalangan) from the Indonesian State College of Arts (STSI) Denpasar Bali Performance and Script: Sumbah (a taleform Mahabharata. Since 1993 has been a Faculty member at the Arts Institute Denpasar, Bali, Indonesia. In 2000 he became Director of Paripurna Art Company, Bona, Gianyar and in 2002 Director of Production of the Theatre Dept. Arts Institute Denpasar
Has worked with hundreds of school students from around the globe, teaching the Wayang Kulit and the Kecak. He recently worked with the Year 9 Drama Students of John Curtin College of the Arts, teaching wayang puppetry, kayonan dances, Kecak dance and traditional makeup and costuming. After only seven weeks on irregular practice, the students performed Made's choreography.
==Credits== "BALI ARTS FESTIVAL" Director of Opening Ceremony 2008, Choreographer for Gong Kebyar Competition
"MOKSA" artistic director of a spectacular production which was presented for the 10th Anniversary of Gunarsa Fine Arts Museum on January 16, 2004 by the Indonesian Arts Institute Denpasar.
"THE THEFT OF SITA" international multi media production, first performed at the Adelaide Festival in 2000 and world tour to United States, Europe, Asia and Australia.
"HARI KESAHATAN" performance for World Environment Day in 2008 in Jakarta
"DIBURU WAKTU" Theatre and multi-media performance, AT 2005 Darwin Festival in collaboration with Australian artistic director, Andrish Saint Clare, written by Sandra Thibodeaux.
Cross Cultural performance at Angkor Wat, Cambodia, 2005 in collaboration with Kambojia performer Mankosal and artistic director Delpin, sponsored by Kelola
Invited to perform and give workshops at UNIMA in Perth in 2008.
==Awards== 1978 as the second winner of Bali Children Puppeteer Competition 2003 my company became the first winner in the 2003 All-Bali Children Gong Kebyar Competition (the VCD enclosed).
==External links== * [http://www.thejakartapost.com/detailheadlines.asp?fileid=20071101.B11&irec=10 Wayang, culinary installation open Art Summit] The Jakarta Post - November 2, 2007 * [http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9B07E2DF123EF93AA25753C1A9679C8B63 NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; A Tale Told by Shadows Blends the Old and the New] [[New York Times]] - October 19, 2001
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sidia, I Made}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indonesian Hindus]] [[Category:Balinese people]] [[Category:Indonesian puppeteers]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Dutch |Jeanne de Belleville |date=January 2014}} {{ infobox pirate | Name = Jeanne Louise de Belleville, de Clisson, Dame de Montaigu | other_names = Jeanne de Belleville | birth_date = 1300 | death_date = 1359 | image = Coat of Arms Clisson Family.jpg | image_size = 150px | alt = A red shield with a white lion rampant | caption = Coat of Arms Clisson Family | nickname = Lioness of Brittany | gender = female | country = Brittany | ethnicity = Breton | type = [[Privateer]] | birth_place = [[Belleville-sur-Vie]] | death_place = [[Hennebont]] | allegiance = [[John IV, Duke of Brittany]] [[File:Armoiries Jean de Montfort.svg|50px|Arms of John of Montfort]] | wealth = | laterwork = |children=[[Olivier de Clisson]] }} '''Jeanne de Clisson''' (1300–1359), also known as '''Jeanne de Belleville''' and the '''Lioness of Brittany''', was a [[Breton people|Breton]] [[privateer]] who plied the [[English Channel]]. Jeanne Louise de Belleville, de Clisson, Dame de [[Montaigu, Vendée|Montaigu]], was born in 1300 in [[Belleville-sur-Vie]] in the [[Vendee]], a daughter of nobleman Maurice IV Montaigu of Belleville and [[Palluau]] (1263–1304) and Létice de Parthenay of [[Parthenay]] (1276–?) in the [[Gâtine Vendéenne]]. == Married at twelve == In 1312, Jeanne married her first husband, 19-year-old Geoffrey de [[Châteaubriant]] VIII (died 1326), a Breton nobleman, and had two children: * Geoffrey IX (1314–1347), inherited his father's estates as Baron, died in the [[Battle of La Roche-Derrien]]; and * Louise (1316–1383), married Guy XII de Laval and inherited her brother's estate as Baroness. == Second marriage == In 1328, Jeanne married, Guy of Penthièvre [[:fr:Guy de Penthièvre|(''fr'')]] [[Counts and dukes of Penthièvre]], widower of Joan of [[Avaugour]] and son of the Duke of Brittany. Jeanne may have done this to protect her underage children. ===Intrigue and Annulment=== The union was short lived as relatives of the Ducal family in particular from the de Blois faction, laid a complaint with the bishops of Vannes and Rennes to protect their heritage and an investigation was conducted on February 10, 1330, resulting in the marriage being annulled by [[Pope John XXII]] in 1330. Guy then married into the de Blois faction to Maire de Blois who was also a niece of Phillip VI of France. Guy however unexpectedly died on the 26th March 1331 and his heritage passed to his daughter [[Joan, Duchess of Brittany|Jeanne of Penthièvre]]. == Third marriage == In 1330, Jeanne remarried to Olivier de Clisson IV, a wealthy Breton, holding a castle at [[Clisson]], a manor house in Nantes and lands at [[Blain, Loire-Atlantique|Blain]]. Olivier was initially married to Blanche de Bouville (died 1329). Jeanne a recent widow herself of the lord of Chateaubriant controlled areas in Poitou just south of the Breton border from [[Beauvoir-sur-Mer]] in the west to [[Cheaumur]] in the southeast of Clisson. Combining these assets would make Jeanne and Olivier the seigneurial power (senior Lord of an area) in the [[March (territorial entity)|marches]]. Jeanne and Olivier had five children: * Isabeau, (1325–1343) born out of wedlock, married John I of Rieux and therefore mother of [[Jean II de Rieux]] (died 1343) and * Maurice, (1333–1334, in Blain) * [[Olivier de Clisson|Olivier V]], (1336–1407),his father's successor, a future [[Constable of France]], nicknamed the butcher * Guillaume, (1338–1345) died of exposure * Jeanne, (1340–?) married Jean Harpedane, Lord of [[Montendre]] IV's successor. == De Clissons choose sides == During the [[Breton War of Succession]], the de Clissons sided with the French choice for the empty Breton ducal crown, [[Charles de Blois]], against the English preference, [[John II of Montfort|John de Montfort]]. The extended de Clisson family was not in full agreement in this matter and Olivier IV's brother, Amaury de Clisson embraced the de Montfort party. == Intrigue of Vannes == In 1342, the English, after four attempts, captured [[Siege of Vannes (1342)|Vannes]]. Her husband Olivier and Hervé VII de Léon, the military commanders defending this city, were captured. Olivier was the only one released after an exchange for [[Ralph de Stafford, 1st Earl of Stafford]] (a prisoner of the French), and a surprisingly low sum was demanded. This led Olivier to be subsequently suspected of not having defended the city to his fullest, and he was alleged by Charles de Blois to be a traitor. == Tournament and trial == On 19 January 1343, the Truce of [[Malestroit]] was signed between England and France. Under the perceived safe conditions of this truce, Olivier and fifteen other Breton lords were invited to a tournament on French soil, where he was arrested, taken to Paris, tried by his peers and on 2 August 1343, executed by beheading at [[Les Halles]].
In the year of our Grace one thousand three hundred and forty-three, on Saturday, the second day of August, Olivier, Lord of Clisson, knight, prisoner in the Chatelet of Paris for several treasons and other crimes perpetrated by him against the king and the crown of France, and for alliances that he made with the king of England, enemy of the king and kingdom of France, as the said Olivier ... has confessed, was by judgement of the king given at Orleans drawn from the Chatelet of Paris to Les Halles ... and there on a scaffold had his head cut off. And then from there his corpse was drawn to the gibbet of Paris and there hanged on the highest level; and his head was sent to [[Nantes]] in Brittany to be put on a lance over the Sauvetout gate as a warning to others.''The Law of Treason and Treason Trials in Later Medieval France'' (''Cambridge Studies in Medieval Life and Thought'': Third Series). 18 December 2003
This execution shocked the nobility as the evidence of guilt was not publicly demonstrated, and the process of exposing a body was reserved mainly for low-class criminals. This execution was judged harshly by [[Froissart]] and his contemporaries.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrionline.ac.uk/onlinefroissart/index.jsp|title=The Online Froissart|website=www.hrionline.ac.uk}} [[File:Exécution d'Olivier IV de Clisson (1343).jpg|thumb|300px|Execution of Olivier IV de Clisson. Painting attributed to Loyset Liédet, Flemish illuminator (v.1420-v.1483) in the "Chronicles of Lord Jehan Froissart ]] == Shock and revenge == Jeanne took her two young sons, Olivier and Guillaume, from Clisson to Nantes, to show them the head of their father at the Sauvetout gate. Jeanne, enraged by her husband's execution, swore retribution against the French King, [[Philip VI of France|Philip VI]], and Charles de Blois. She considered their actions a cowardly murder. == Change of allegiances == Jeanne then sold the de Clisson estates, raised a force of loyal men and started attacking French forces in Brittany. Jeanne is said to have attacked a castle at Touffou and a castle occupied by Galois de la Heuse, an officer of Charles de Blois, massacring the entire garrison with the exception of one individual. Jeanne also attacked another garrison at [[Château-Thébaud]], about 20 km south east of Nantes which had been a former post under control of her husband. == Black Fleet == With the English king's assistance and Breton sympathizers, Jeanne outfitted three warships. These were painted black and their sails dyed red. The flagship was named ''My Revenge''. The ships of this Black Fleet then patrolled the English Channel hunting down French ships, whereupon her force would kill entire crews, leaving only a few witnesses to transmit the news to the French King. This earned Jeanne the moniker "The Lioness of Brittany". Jeanne continued her piracy in the channel for another 13 years. Jeanne is also said to have attacked coastal villages in Normandy and have put several to sword and fire. In 1346, during the [[Battle of Crecy]], south of [[Calais]], in northern France, Jeanne used her ships to supply the English forces. After the sinking of her flagship, Jeanne with her two sons were adrift for five days, her son Guillaume died of exposure. Jeanne and Olivier were finally rescued and taken to [[Morlaix]] by Montfort supporters. == Fourth marriage == In 1356, Jeanne married for a fourth time to [[Sir Walter Bentley (soldier)|Sir Walter Bentley]], one of [[King Edward III]]'s military deputies during the campaign. Bentley had previously won the [[battle of Mauron]] on 4 August 1352 and was rewarded for his services with "the lands and castles" Beauvoir-sur-mer, of Ampant, of Barre, Blaye, Châteauneuf, Ville Maine, the island Chauvet and from the islands of Noirmoutier and Bouin.{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/battles_mauron.html|title=Battle of Mauron, 14 August 1352 (Brittany)|website=www.historyofwar.org}} Jeanne finally settled at the Castle of [[Hennebont]], a port town on the Brittany coast, which was in the territory of her de Montfort allies, where she died in 1359. == Historical evidence == Verifiable references relating to Jeanne’s exploits are limited, but do exist. These include: * A French judgement from 1343 convicting Jeanne as a traitor and confirmed the confiscation of the de Clisson lands. * Records from the English court from 1343, indicating King Edward granting Jeanne an income from lands controlled in Brittany by the English. * Jeanne is mentioned in the truce between France and England in 1347 as an English ally. (Treaty of Calais, 28 September 1347)Wagner, J. A. ''Encyclopedia of the Hundred Years War'' {{ISBN|0-313-32736-X}}, Greenwood Press, 2006 * A 15th-century manuscript, known as the ''Chronographia Regum Francorum'', confirms some of the details of her life.Régis Rech. "[http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopedia-of-the-medieval-chronicle/chronographia-regum-francorum-SIM_00727 Chronographia regum Francorum]". ''Encyclopedia of the Medieval Chronicle''. Edited by Graeme Dunphy. Brill Online, 2014. 30 October 2014 * Amaury de Clisson, the brother of Olivier, is used as an emissary from [[Joanna of Flanders]] (Jehanne de Montfort) to ask King Edward III for aid to relieve Hennebont. The de Clisson family was at that stage definitely on the de Montfort side. * Records exist where shortly after Olivier de Clisson's execution, several other knights were accused of similar crimes. The lord of Malestroit and his son, the lord of Avaugour, sir Tibaut de Morillon, and other lords of Brittany, to the number of ten knights and squires, were beheaded at Paris. Four other knights of Normandy, sir William Baron, sir Henry de Malestroit, the lord of Rochetesson, and Sir Richard de Persy, were put to death upon reports. * The name of Jeanne de Belleville is also attached to the Breviary of Belleville, a book of prayers that follow the liturgical year. This manuscript in Latin and in French and in two volumes dated around 1323-1326 with illuminations by Jean Pucelle . Jeanne de Belleville would have received it as a gift for her wedding with Olivier in 1328. Around 1379-1380, an inventory was made of King Charles V property and the breviary was described herein. * Great Chronicles of France, t.5, of John (II) the Good to Charles (V) the Wise (1350/1380); * Latin chronicle of Guillaume de Nangis and his continuations, (1317/1368); * Chronicles of the first four Valois, (1327/1393) * Chronicles of Mont-Saint-Michel, t.1 (1343/1432) == Literature == In 1868, French writer Émile Pehant's novel ''Jeanne de Belleville'' was published in France. Written at the height of the French romantic movement, Pehant's novel shares many details with the legend attached to Jeanne. == See also == *[[Olivier de Clisson]], V, her son *[[Belleville Breviary]], a book of prayers == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == *{{Citation |first=Françoise |last=d'Eaubonne |authorlink=Françoise d'Eaubonne |date=1998 |title=Les grandes aventurieres |language=French |publisher=Vernal and Philippe Lebaud |location=Saint-Amard-Montrond |isbn=2865940381 |pages=17–27}} *{{Citation |first=Michael |last=Hearst |authorlink=Michael Hearst |date=2015 |title=Extraordinary People |language=English |publisher=Chronicle |location=San Francisco |isbn=978-1-4521-2709-5 |pages=28–29}} *{{Citation |first=Jean |last=Froissart |first2=Auguste |last2=Scheler |date=1875 |title=Oeuvres de Froissart: publiées avec les variantes des divers manuscrits |volume=21 |page=12 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RF0kAa1r160C&pg=PA12}} *{{Citation |first=John Bell |last=Henneman |date=June 1996 |title=Olivier de Clisson and political society in France under Charles V and Charles VI |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |location=Philadelphia}} *{{Citation |first=Gérard A. |last=Jaeger |date=1984 |title=Les femmes d'abordage: Chroniques historiques et legendaires des aventurières de la mer |publisher=Clancier-Guénaud |location=Paris |pages=31–39}} *{{Citation |first=Gilles |last=Lapouge |date=1987 |title=Les Pirates, forbans, flibustiers, boucaniers et autres gueux de mer}} *{{Citation |first=Yvonig |last=Gicquel |title=Olivier de Clisson, connétable de France ou chef de parti breton? |publisher=Jean Picollec |location=París |date=1981 |pages=39–41 |isbn=2-86477-025-3}} *{{Citation |first=Philippe |last=Richard |title=Olivier de Clisson, connétable de France, grand seigneur breton |publisher=Ediciones Opéra |location=Haute-Goulaine |date=2007 |pages=39–43 |isbn=978-2-35370-030-1}} *{{Citation |first=Trina |last=Robbins |date=2004 |title=Wild Irish Roses: Tales of Brigits, Kathleens, and Warrior Queens |pages=115–116 |publisher=Conari Press |isbn=1-57324-952-1}} *{{Citation |first=Anne |last=de Tourville |date=1958 |title=Femmes de la mer |publisher=Le Livre Contemporain |location=Paris |pages=37–47}} *{{Citation |first=Germán |last=Vázquez Chamorro |date=October 2004 |title=Mujeres Piratas |language=Spanish |chapter=Jeanne de Classon. La leona sangrienta |pages=107–115 |publisher=Algaba |isbn=84-96107-26-4}} *{{Citation |first=Marie-Ève |last=Sténuit|date=2015|title=pirates Women: the foamy sea|language=French |isbn=979-1-09-153415-4}} == External links == *[http://h2g2.com/edited_entry/A14066408 Jeanne de Clisson at h2g2] *[http://www.jamesadamshistoricenterprises.com/treasuretrove/jeandeclisson.html Jeanne de Belleville, Pirate or Politician? - James Adams Historic Enterprises] {{pirates}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clisson, Jeanne de}} [[Category:1300 births]] [[Category:1359 deaths]] [[Category:Female pirates]] [[Category:Medieval pirates]] [[Category:People from Loire-Atlantique]] [[Category:People of the Hundred Years' War]] [[Category:14th-century French people]] [[Category:14th-century French women]] [[Category:Women in war]]

{{Other|Kosoko (name)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Kosoko | title = [[Oba of Lagos]] | titletext = | more = | type = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption =
| succession = | moretext = | reign = 1845–1851 | reign-type = | coronation = | cor-type = | predecessor = [[Akitoye]] | pre-type = | successor = [[Akitoye]] | suc-type = | regent = | reg-type =
| birth_name = Kosoko | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | birth_place = Lagos | death_date = 1872 | death_place = Lagos | burial_date = | burial_place = Iga Ereko, Lagos | spouse = | spouse-type = | consort = <!-- yes or no --> | issue = | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | issue-type = | full name = | era name = | era dates = | regnal name = | posthumous name = | temple name = | house = [[Ado (Lagos Oba)|Ado]], Ologun Kutere, Osinlokun | house-type = | father = Osinlokun | mother =
| religion = | occupation = | signature_type = | signature = }}
'''Kosoko''' (died 1872) was a member of the [[Ologun Kutere]] Lagos Royal Family who reigned as [[Oba of Lagos]] from 1845 to 1851. His father was Oba [[Osinlokun]] and his siblings were [[Idewu Ojulari]] (who was Oba from 1829 to 1834/35) and Opo Olu, a wealthy and powerful female slave holder.<ref name="Mann-45">{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Kristin|title=Slavery and the Birth of an African City: Lagos, 1760–1900|publisher=Indiana University Press, 2007|isbn=9780253348845|page=45}}</ref>
==Ascendancy== Kosoko's ascendancy to the Obaship of Lagos in 1845 was predated by a series of dramatic events.
===Rift between the Osinlokun and Adele lines=== When Oba [[Ologun Kutere]] died (between 1800 and 1805), a succession struggle ensued between his older son (Osinlokun) and his younger and preferred son (Adele). Though the kingship was not determined by birth order but by Kingmakers and a consultation of the [[Ifá|Ifa Oracle]], Osinlokun and his followers mounted opposition to Adele's kingship.<ref name="Smith-Struggle">{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851–1861|publisher=University of California Press, 1979|isbn=9780520037465|pages=14–17}}</ref> Adele's reign was then cut short in 1821 by his older brother, Osinlokun, around 1821, forcing Adele to exile to [[Badagry]] where he assumed headship of the town.
===Genesis of Kosoko's feud with Eletu Odibo=== Kosoko offended the powerful prime minister ([[Eletu Odibo]])and Kingmaker by marrying a woman betrothed to Chief Eletu Odibo.<ref name="Mann-Odibo-Kosoko">{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Kristin|title=Slavery and the Birth of an African City: Lagos, 1760—1900|publisher=Indiana University Press, 2007|isbn=9780253117083|pages=47–49}}</ref> Eletu Odibo, as head of the Akarigbere class of chiefs, was vested with the authority to oversee the selection and installation of obas. Kosoko's arrogant decision would come to haunt his bid for the throne as Chief Eletu Odibo took great offense and the feud between both men altered the Obaship succession many times and set the stage for British intervention in Lagos later in 1851.<ref name="Mann-Odibo-Kosoko" />
===Osinlokun's death, Idewu Ojulari's short term, and manifestation of the Eletu and Kosoko feud=== When Osinlokun died in 1829, Kosoko's brother, Idewu Ojulari, became Oba and reigned from 1829 to around 1834/5. However, Idewu Ojulari's reign was unpopular and at the behest of the [[Oba of Benin]], to whom the people of Lagos had petitioned, Idewu Ojulari committed suicide. Notably, Lagos had hitherto been under Benin suzerainty up until the reign of Oba Kosoko who was dethroned by British forces in 1851. Thereafter, Oba Akitoye and his successor, Oba Dosunmu, rebuffed payment of annual tributes to Benin.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851–1861|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=0333240545|pages=90}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ryder|first1=Alan Frederick Charles|title=Benin and the Europeans: 1485–1897|publisher=Humanities Press, 1969 – Benin|pages=241–242}}</ref>
Since Kosoko was now unacceptable to Eletu Odibo, the Kingmakers invited Adele home from Badagry to rule as Oba of Lagos for a second term. Oba Adele's second reign terminated upon his death in 1837 and again, Eletu Odibo blocked Kosoko's accession and installed [[Oluwole]], Adele's son.
===Increased strife between Kosoko and Eletu Odibo's allies=== The intensity of the Eletu Odibo and Kosoko feud increased with Eletu Odibo extending his vendetta to Opo Olu, Kosoko's sister, accusing her of witchcraft.<ref name="Mann-Odibo-Kosoko" /> The diviners found Opo Olu innocent however Oba Oluwole banished Opo Olu from Lagos, leading Kosoko and his followers to pursue a failed armed uprising known as Ogun Ewe Koko ("leaves of the coco-yam war") which resulted in Kosoko and his followers fleeing to Epe.<ref name="Smith-Struggle" />
Eletu Odibo then ratcheted up the hatred between both camps by digging up Kosoko's mother's remains and throwing her corpse into the Lagos lagoon.<ref name="Mann-Odibo-Kosoko" />
===Oba Oluwole's death and Akitoye's ascendancy=== Oba [[Oluwole]] was killed in 1841 when lighting triggered an explosion at the Oba's place. Oluwole's body was blown to pieces and could only be identified by his royal beads adorning his body. Kingmakers would have invited Kosoko to become Oba but his whereabouts were unknown. <ref name="Smith-Struggle" /><ref name="Mann-Odibo-Kosoko" /> Consequently, [[Akitoye]], Kosoko's uncle, younger brother to Osinlokun & Adele, and son of [[Ologun Kutere]] was installed as Oba of Lagos.
===Akitoye's naivety and Kosoko's revenge === In an attempt at reconciliation (met with fierce resistance from chiefs, not least Eletu Odibo) with his nephew, Oba Akitoye naively recalled Kosoko to Lagos. Kosoko returned to Lagos aboard the ship of the famous slave trader Jose Domingo Martinez. Akitoye tried to placate Kosoko with gifts and granted him the title Oloja of Ereko or owner of Ereko. Kosoko quickly consolidated his position and found support among many war chiefs and among the Muslim community. Eletu Odibo was concerned with Kosoko's power consolidation and departed for Badagry. In turn, Akitoye recalled Eletu Odibo from Badagry, leading Kosoko to declare that if Eletu Odibo returned to Lagos, he would "make himself king".
A war of words ensued between Oba Akitoye and Kosoko sending his crier around Lagos singing "Tell that little child at court yonder to be careful; for if he is not careful he will be punished". Akitoye deployed his crier singing "I am like a pin firmly driven into the ground, which is always hard to root out but ever remains firm". Kosoko retorted "I am the digger who always roots out a pin".<ref name="Mann-Odibo-Kosoko" />
The tensions led to an rising named Ogun Olomiro (Salt Water War) by the Kosoko faction in July 1845. The Kosoko faction laid siege to the Oba's Palace for three weeks. Akitoye eventually accepted defeat, escaped up the lagoon to the north, and was granted safe passage through the Agboyi Creek by [[Oshodi Tapa]], Kosoko's war captain. Oshodi Tapa explained Akitoye's escape to Kosoko by saying that Akitoye put his enemies in a trance. Akitoye thereafter arrived in Abeokuta where he was granted asylum.<ref name="Smith-Struggle" /> Recognizing Akitoye's escape as a threat, Kosoko demanded Akitoye's head from the Egbas who refused Kosoko's demands. In March 1845, the Egbas provided the now deposed Akitoye with an escort to Badagry, the traditional town of refuge for Lagosians where he rallied his followers and built a partnership with European missionaries and with the British through their Consul [[John Beecroft]].
Importantly, Eletu Odibo was captured in the battle and Kosoko avenged the scattering of his mother's bones by the Eletu by placing Eletu Odibo in an empty oil barrel, sealing it, setting it alight, and dumping it in the Lagos Lagoon.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=Patrick|title=Modern and Traditional Elites in the Politics of Lagos|publisher=Cambridge University Press, 1975|isbn=9780521204392|page=195 n39}}</ref><ref name="Mann-Odibo-Kosoko" /><ref name="JHK">{{cite book|last1=Herskovits Kopytoff|first1=Jean|title=A Preface to Modern Nigeria: The "Sierra Leoneans" in Yoruba, 1830 – 1890|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press|pages=64–66}}</ref>
==British intervention in Lagos, Kosoko's removal and Akitoye's re-installation as Oba== A confluence of interests in Lagos from the now deposed Akitoye who allied himself with the anti-slavery cause in order to get British support, the Anglican missionaries in Badagry who were in contact with Akitoye, and Egba and European traders who wanted freer movement of goods ratcheted up British intervention in Lagos. Akitoye's anti-slavery position appears born of self-interest considering his connection with the well known slave trader Domingo Martinez who backed Akitoyes's unsuccessful attack on Lagos in 1846.
In November 1851 a British party met with Oba Kosoko to present a proposal of British friendly relations along with giving up the [[Trans Atlantic Slave Trade]]. The proposal was rejected by Kosoko "on the technical reason that Lagos was under the [[Oba of Benin]] and that it was only that Oba who could deal with foreign powers concerning the status of Lagos"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Onabamiro|first1=Sanya|title=Glimpses Into Nigerian History: Historical Essays|publisher=Macmillan Nigeria, 1983|isbn=9789781327292|page=43}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dioka|first1=L.C.|title=Lagos and Its Environs|publisher=First Academic, 2001|isbn=9789783490253|page=75}}</ref>
On 4 December 1851, upon Kosoko's successful repulsion and defeat of British forces, Consul Beecroft wrote to the [[Oba of Benin]] declaring that "Kosoko, by opening fire on a flag of truce, had declared war on England" and therefore had to be replaced by Akitoye. He threatened that Kosoko had till the end of the month to surrender otherwise "Lagos would be totally destroyed by fire". <ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851–1861|publisher=University of California Press, 1979|isbn=9780520037465|page=27}}</ref>
On 26 December 1851, in what is now known as the [[Bombardment of Lagos]] or [[Reduction of Lagos]], ''HMS Bloodhound'', ''HMS Teazer'', and a flotilla of boats mounted an attack on the Oba's palace. Kosoko put up a spirited defense but by 28 December 1851 the battle known locally as Ogun Ahoyaya or Ogun Agidingbi (after boiling cannons) was over with Kosoko and his followers fleeing to Ijebu. Akitoye was now installed Oba of Lagos with British support.
On 1 January 1852 Akitoye signed the [[Treaty Between Great Britain and Lagos, 1 January 1852|Treaty between Great Britain and Lagos]] abolishing the slave trade.
==Kosoko in exile at Epe== Kosoko eventually settled in Epe with the permission of the Awujale of Ijebu. Epe was the place where about 15 years earlier a number of his followers such as his chiefs Dada Antonio and Osho Akanbi had taken refuge. By 1852, Kosoko had built up an independent base with about 400 warriors (including [[Oshodi Tapa]]) to mount his opposition to Akitoye.
In 1853 Kosoko mounted two attacks on Lagos; one on 5 August 1853 and another on 11 August 1853 which came dangerously close to the Oba's palace but was rebuffed just in time by a burst of fire from the British naval force under Commander Phillips of HMS Polyphemus.
Kosoko eventually signed [[The Treaty of Epe]] on 28 September 1854 with Consul [[Benjamin Campbell (consular agent)|Benjamin Campbell]], agreeing not to make any claims to Lagos or to endanger commerce in Lagos. The treaty was a tactical success for Kosoko who got the British to recognize his state in Epe. In the big picture, however, the Lagos throne remained out of reach with Akitoye and Dosunmu's descendants firmly rooted.
==Kosoko's return to Lagos after Annexation as a Crown Colony in 1861== In 1860, Kosoko persuaded the [[Oba of Benin]] to send messages to Dosunmu pressing him to allow Kosoko's return to Lagos. Dosunmu, now under British authority, refused this request and noted that things were "not as in former times when Lagos was under the King of Benin to whom annually a tribute was paid" <ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851–1861|publisher=University of California Press, 1979|isbn=9780520037465|page=102}}</ref>
After Britain annexed Lagos via the [[Lagos Treaty of Cession|Treaty of 1861]], Kosoko was allowed to return to Lagos with the title of Oloja of Ereko, receiving a pension of £400 annually. Oshodi Tapa, settled in Epetedo.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851–1861|publisher=University of California Press, 1979|isbn=9780520037465|page=127}}</ref>
==Death and legacy== Kosoko died in 1872 and was buried at Iga Ereko in Lagos.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851–1861|publisher=University of California Press, 1979|isbn=9780520037465|page=175 n 67}}</ref> The Kosoko-Akitoye/Dosunmu rivalry spilled over into the economic realm. Oba Dosunmu's supporters didn't fully appreciate the British presence in Lagos, while Kosoko's allies exploited the relationship. Kosoko's camp comprised men such as [[Oshodi Tapa]] and [[Taiwo Olowo]], who enthusiastically entered into trade with European firms. At the head of the Dosunmu economic faction was Chief Apena Ajasa, who repeatedly clashed with Taiwo Olowo. When Kosoko died, the colonial government estimated that his economic faction was the more powerful one due to the fact that it was composed of at least 20,000 followers.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=Patrick|title=Modern and Traditional Elites in the Politics of Lagos|publisher=Cambridge University Press, 1975|isbn=9780521204392|page=28}}</ref>
A prominent descendant of his is [[Oba (ruler)#Oloye|Omoba]] [[Jide Kosoko]], a noted [[Nollywood]] actor.
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=September 2011}} '''Krystyna Ceynowa''', also spelled as ''Cejnowa'' (died 1836), was an ethnic Polish victim of [[murder]] by [[lynching]] and an alleged [[Witchcraft|witch]] in [[Germany]]. Accused of [[Magic (paranormal)|sorcery]], she was subjected to the [[Trial by ordeal|ordeal]] of water and drowned in [[Chałupy|Ceynowa]] (today Chałupy). She was among the last people in [[Europe]] to be subjected to [[lynching]] on the grounds of sorcery and witchcraft.
== Background == Krystyna Ceynowa was the [[widow]] of a [[fisherman]], living at [[Chałupy|Ceynowa]] on the [[Hel Peninsula]], in the German [[Province of Prussia]]. She was regarded as suspicious by the community for various reasons, including the fact that she never went to church, and it was said that black [[crow]]s were attracted to her [[chimney]] .This gave her a bad reputation in the eyes of the congregation and people suspected that she was a witch. However, the authorities at that time were not willing to conduct a witch trial.
== The murder ==
She was taken captive by a lynch mob determined to test her to see if she was a witch. Her suppressors were called from [[Sopot|Zoppot]], and she was subjected to the ordeal of water during an illegal trial. The ordeal took place in the [[Baltic Sea]] - she was transported in a boat and thrown overboard. To the disbelief of many, she remained afloat for a long time, which was taken as an evidence of witchcraft, whereas nobody thought that her gown and skirt had acted as a buoy. When Ceynowa did not drown, the people found her to be a real witch and killed her with their paddles.
Her case demonstrates that a belief in witchcraft continued among the public long after the legal authorities stopped accepting the charges of witchcraft, and that people occasionally took the law into their own hands when they suspected witchcraft.
== See also == * [[Dummy, the Witch of Sible Hedingham]] * [[Anna Klemens]] * [[Barbara Zdunk]]
== References == * http://www.wladyslawowo.com.pl/e_chalupy.html * http://www.qi.com/talk/viewtopic.php?t=12226&postdays=0&postorder=asc&start=30 * Klaus Klöppel, Olaf Matthei: ''Polnische Ostseeküste'' (The Polish East coast) * Nils Freytag: ''Hexenglauben im 19. Jahrhundert'' (Witch hunt in the 19th-century)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ceynowa, Krystyna}} [[Category:1836 deaths]] [[Category:Lynching deaths]] [[Category:Polish murder victims]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Witchcraft]] [[Category:19th-century Polish people]] {{poland-bio-stub}} {{crime-bio-stub}}

page.title: List of women in the Heritage Floor

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of women in the ''Heritage Floor''}} This list documents all 998 mythical, historical and notable women whose names are displayed on the handmade white tiles of the ''Heritage Floor'' as part of [[Judy Chicago]]'s ''[[The Dinner Party]]'' art installation (1979); there is also one man listed, [[Kresilas]], who was mistakenly included in the installation as he was thought to have been a woman called Cresilla. The names appear as they are spelled on the floor. Since 2007 the installation has been on permanent exhibition in the [[Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art]] at the [[Brooklyn Museum]], New York.
{{Compact ToC|q=|w=[[#W–Z|W–Z]]|x=|y=|z=|center=yes|align=center|notesfirst=yes|refs=yes}} :''This is a sortable list. Click on the column headers to reorder.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%;" |- ! Name ! Birthdate ! Location ! Group (Related Place Setting) ! class="unsortable"|Notes |- | {{anchor|A}}[[Abella|Abella of Salerno]] | {{Hs|1350}}Flourished c. 1350 | [[Salerno, Italy]] | Trotula | Taught general medicine at [[Schola Medica Salernitana]], the earliest medical school in Europe. She specialised in [[embryology]],<ref name="Herbermann1912">{{cite book|author=Charles George Herbermann|title=The Catholic encyclopedia;: an international work of reference on the constitution, doctrine, discipline, and history of the Catholic church;|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=800fAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA398|accessdate=12 December 2011|year=1912|publisher=Appleton|page=398}}</ref> and published two treatises.<ref name="Abella">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Abella of Salerno | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Abella of Salerno | publisher=[[Brooklyn Museum]] | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/abella_of_salerno.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Abigail]] | {{Hs|-965}}Flourished c. 965 BC<ref name="Abigail2" /> | Ancient [[Israelites|Israel]] | Judith | Earliest female pacifist in biblical record.<ref name="C69">Chicago, 69.</ref> Her husband defied the future [[King David]] and to avoid war, she went behind her husband's back and prepared food for David, in order to keep the peace. Her husband died from the shock of her actions, and she would go on to become the third wife of David.<ref name="Abigail2">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Abigail | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Abigail | publisher=Brooklyn Museum| url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/abigail.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="C69" /> |- | [[Abigail Adams]] | {{Hs|1744}} 1744 | [[Massachusetts]], United States | Anne Hutchinson | [[Abolitionism in the United States|Abolitionist]], women's education advocate, influential political figure.<ref name="AbigailAdams">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Abigail Adams | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Abigail Adams | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/abigail_adams.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Adela of Blois]] | {{Hs|1067}}c. 1067<ref name="Schaus2006" /> | France | Eleanor of Aquitaine | Filled as regent while her husband, [[Stephen II, Count of Blois|Stephen Henry]], participated in the [[First Crusade]].<ref name="Schaus2006">{{cite book|author=Margaret Schaus|title=Women and gender in medieval Europe: an encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aDhOv6hgN2IC&pg=PA6|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=2006|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-415-96944-4|page=6}}</ref><ref name="AdelaBlois">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Adela of Blois | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Adela of Blois | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/adela_of_blois.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Adela Zamudio-Ribero]] | {{Hs|1854}}1854<ref name="Adela2" /> | [[Cochabamba]], [[Bolivia]]<ref name="Adela2" /> | Virginia Woolf | Poet, intellectual and founder of the Bolivian feminist movement.<ref name="Adela2">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Adela Zambudia-Ribero | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Adela Zambudia-Ribero | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/adela_zambudia_ribero.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Adelaide of Italy|Adelaide]] | {{Hs|931}}931<ref name="C104" /> | France | Theodora | Empress of the [[Holy Roman Empire]].<ref name="C104">Chicago, 104.</ref><ref name="Adelaide2">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Adelaide | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Adelaide| publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/adelaide.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Adélaïde Labille-Guiard|Adelaide Labille-Guiard]] | {{Hs|1749}}1749 | France | Artemisia Gentileschi | Portrait painter, member of the [[Académie Royale]], women's education advocate.<ref name="Adelaide1">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Adelaide Labille-Guiard | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Adelaide Labille-Guiard | publisher=Brooklyn Museum| url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/adelaide_labille_guiard.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="C157">Chicago, 157.</ref> |- | {{sort|Adelaide Susa|[[Adelaide of Susa]]}} | {{Hs|1016}}c. 1016 | Italy | Eleanor of Aquitaine | Philanthropist, heiress, countess of Savoy.<ref name="AdelaideofSusa">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Adelaide of Susa | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Adelaide of Susa| publisher=Brooklyn Museum| url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/adelaide_of_susa.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> She also led an army to defend [[Turin]].<ref name="C121" /> |- | [[Adelberger]] | {{Hs|701}}8th century | Italy | Trotula | Physician, member of the Guild of Lay Healers.<ref name="C116">Chicago, 116.</ref> Possibly [[Adelperga]], daughter of [[Desiderius]], who fought against Charlemagne. Little to no information is easily available about the lay healer, Adelberger. |- | [[Adelheid Popp]] | {{Hs|1869}}1869 | Vienna, Austria | Susan B. Anthony | Leader of the [[Austrian Socialist Women's Movement]], served in Austrian government.<ref name="C210">Chicago, 210.</ref> |- | [[Aelia Eudocia|Eudocia]] | {{Hs|400}}c. 400<ref name="LightmanLightman2007">{{cite book|author1=Marjorie Lightman|author2=Benjamin Lightman|title=A to Z of ancient Greek and Roman women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2esYJJUETiYC&pg=PA115|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=December 2007|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6710-7|page=115}}</ref> | Athens; Jerusalem | Theodora | Philanthropist, politician, poet, was an Orthodox Christian who fought for the protection of Jews and pagans<ref name="LightmanLightman2007" /><ref name="Eudocia">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Eudocia | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Eudocia | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/eudocia.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Aelia Eudoxia|Eudoxia]] | {{Hs|380}}380<ref name="LightmanLightman2007cxx">{{cite book|author1=Marjorie Lightman|author2=Benjamin Lightman|title=A to Z of ancient Greek and Roman women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2esYJJUETiYC&pg=PA125|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=December 2007|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6710-7|page=120}}</ref> | [[Constantinople]] | Theodora | Empress of Byzantium who influenced the political work of her husband, Emperor Arcadius.<ref name="LightmanLightman2007" /><ref name="C106">Chicago, 106.</ref> |- | [[Aemilia (physician)|Aemilia]] | {{Hs|300}}c. 300 | Gaul | Hypatia | Poet and physician, rejected marriage as it was a hindrance to her career.<ref name="Aemilia">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Aemilia | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Aemilia | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/aemilia.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> Wrote books about gynecology and obstetrics.<ref name="C86">Chicago, 86.</ref> |- | {{sort|Aethelburg|[[Æthelburg of Wessex|Æthelburg]]}} | {{Hs|673}}c. 673 | England | Theodora | Queen of Wessex alongside husband King Ine of Wessex. Fought battles alongside Ine. In 728 they relinquished the crown to her brother and lived amongst the poor in Rome.<ref name="C105">Chicago, 105.</ref> |- | [[Æthelburh of Kent|Ethelberga]] | {{Hs|614}}c. 614<ref name="Hartley2003">{{cite book|author=Cathy Hartley|title=A historical dictionary of British women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pc1UA3uhUlYC&pg=PA15|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=17 December 2003|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-85743-228-2|pages=14–15}}</ref> | England | Hrosvitha | Daughter of [[Bertha of Kent]] and [[Æthelberht of Kent]]. After her husband, [[King Edwin of Northumbria]], died, she founded the first [[Benedictine]] nunnery in England.<ref name="C111">Chicago, 111.</ref> |- | {{sort|Aethelflaed|[[Æthelflæd]]}} | {{Hs|869}}869 | England | Theodora | Led troops against the [[Vikings]]. After her husband, [[Æthelred of Mercia|Æthelred]] died, she became the sole ruler of [[Mercia]].<ref name="Schaus2006x">{{cite book|author=Margaret Schaus|title=Women and gender in medieval Europe: an encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aDhOv6hgN2IC&pg=PA10|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=2006|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-415-96944-4|page=10}}</ref><ref name="C105" /> |- | [[Agatha of Sicily|Agatha]] | {{Hs|235}}c. 235<ref name="Gallick2007">{{cite book|author=Sarah Gallick|title=The big book of women saints|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sjWsJZlJPNsC&pg=PA45|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=13 March 2007|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-082512-6|page=45}}</ref> | Sicily | Hypatia | Rejected the advances of Roman military officials and was tortured by having her breasts cut off,<ref name="C86" /> then, she was sentenced to burn at the stake but was saved by an earthquake. She died in prison and was canonized by the Church.<ref name="Gallick2007" /> She is the patron saint of breast cancer patients.<ref name="Agatha1">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Agatha | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Agatha | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/agatha.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Ageltrude|Ageltrude Benevento]] | {{Hs|801}}9th century | Italy | Trotula | Holy Roman Empress. Used her political power to have her son, [[Lambert II of Spoleto|Lambert]], confirmed as Roman emperor and also to support the election of [[Pope Stephen VI]].<ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/ageltrude_benevento.php "Ageltrude Benevento"]. ''Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: ''. Brooklyn Museum. 2007. Retrieved 1 February 2014.</ref> |- | [[Aglaonice]] | {{Hs|-200}}Between 2nd and 4th century BC<ref name="LightmanLightman2007ix">{{cite book|author1=Marjorie Lightman|author2=Benjamin Lightman|title=A to Z of ancient Greek and Roman women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2esYJJUETiYC&pg=PA9|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=December 2007|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6710-7|page=9}}</ref><ref name="C78" /><ref name="Aglaonice" /> | Greece | Aspasia | Believed to be the first woman astronomer. She could predict [[lunar eclipse]]s and was accused of sorcery; as people believed her ability to predict was actually the ability to create the eclipses.<ref name="LightmanLightman2007" /><ref name="C78">Chicago, 78.</ref><ref name="Aglaonice">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Aglaonice | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Aglaonice | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/aglaonice.php | accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Agnes d'Harcourt]] | {{Hs|1201}}13th century | France | Hildegarde of Bingen | [[Abbess]] of the [[Abbey of Longchamp]] and author. She wrote the first biography about [[Saint Isabel of France|Saint Isabel]], whom she also served as personal assistant to.<ref name="C129">Chicago, 129.</ref><ref name="Agnes2">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Agnes D'Harcourt | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Agnes D'Harcourt | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/agnes_d_harcourt.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Agnes II, Abbess of Quedlinburg|Agnes]] | {{Hs|1184}}Flourished c. 1184 | Germany | Hrosvitha | Abbess of St. Mary's in Quedlinburg, where fine needlework and weavings were created, as well as manuscript illustrations. Agnes encouraged artistic creation and supported a healthy art industry with her nuns' creations.<ref name="C109">Chicago, 109.</ref><ref name="Agnes3">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Agnes Waterhouse | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Agnes | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/agnes_hrosvitha_group.php | accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Agnes of Bohemia|Agnes]] | {{Hs|1211}}1211<ref name="Gallick2007lxxvi">{{cite book|author=Sarah Gallick|title=The big book of women saints|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sjWsJZlJPNsC&pg=PA76|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=13 March 2007|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-082512-6|page=76}}</ref> | Bohemia | Hildegarde of Bingen | Former Bohemian princess who founded the [[Poor Clares]] religious order, an abbey, and a hospital. Canonized in 1989, she is the patron saint of Bohemia.<ref name="Agnes2" /> |- | [[Agnes of Poitou]] | {{Hs|1025}}c. 1024<ref name="Jackson-Laufer1999">{{cite book|author=Guida Myrl Jackson-Laufer|title=Women rulers throughout the ages: an illustrated guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x3BzmTdQLioC&pg=PA11|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=1999|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-091-8|pages=11–12}}</ref> | France | Eleanor of Aquitaine | Second wife of [[Henry III, Holy Roman Emperor]]; she governed the empire until her son, [[Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Henry IV]] came of age to rule.<ref name="C121">Chicago, 121.</ref> She opposed [[Pope Gregory VII]] and helped to elect [[Cadalus]], his rival, to throne. In 1062 her son Henry was kidnapped, and as ransom to save his life, she resigned as regent and remained the rest of her life in a convent.<ref name="Jackson-Laufer1999" /> |- | [[Agnes Randolph|Agnes of Dunbar]] | {{Hs|1312}}1312 | Scotland | Christine de Pisan | Known as "Black Agnes," she successfully defended her family's castle while her husband, [[Patrick V, Earl of March]], was at war, in 1337.<ref name="C138">Chicago, 138.</ref><ref name="Dunbar1">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Agnes of Dunbar | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Agnes of Dunbar | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/agnes_of_dunbar.php | accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Agnes Sampson]] | {{Hs|1501}}16th century | Scotland | Petronilla de Meath | Healer, she was a chief witness at the [[North Berwick witch trials]]. She was tortured, and forced to confess to conspiring with 200 other women to work with the devil to try to kill [[King James VI]]. She was found guilty and executed in 1591.<ref name="C135">Chicago, 135.</ref><ref name="Sampson1">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Agnes Sampson | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Agnes Sampson | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/agnes_sampson.php | accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref> |- | [[Agnes Smedley]] | {{Hs|1892}}1892 | United States | Virginia Woolf | Journalist, who traveled to Berlin in 1920 and helped opened Germany's first [[birth control]] clinic. She continued to travel the world, seeing human and political rights violations first hand. She wrote numerous books, including an autobiography and coverage on China during World War II.<ref name="C255256">Chicago, 255–256.</ref><ref name="Smedley">{{cite web | author= | year=2011 | title=Agnes Smedley | work=Master spies | publisher=Spy Museum | url=http://www.spymuseum.com/pages/agent-smedley-agnes.html | accessdate=13 December 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201062942/http://www.spymuseum.com/pages/agent-smedley-agnes.html | archivedate=1 December 2011 | df= }}</ref> |- | [[Agnès Sorel]] | {{Hs|1422}}c. 1422<ref name="Sorel1">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Agnes Sorel | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Agnes Sorel | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/agnes_sorel.php | accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="PrioleauPrioleau2004">{{cite book|author1=Betsy Prioleau|author2=Elizabeth Stevens Prioleau|title=Seductress: Women Who Ravished the World and Their Lost Art of Love|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MWsCVWCH8V0C&pg=PT210|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=26 October 2004|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0-14-303422-3|pages=210–211}}</ref> | France | Isabella d'Este | Mistress of [[King Charles VII of France]] and the first to be publicly acknowledged.<ref name="PrioleauPrioleau2004" /><ref name="C146">Chicago, 146.</ref> All four of their children were also acknowledged and she died of [[dysentery]] at age 28, but some believe she was poisoned.<ref name="PrioleauPrioleau2004" /> |- | [[Agnes Waterhouse]] | {{Hs|1503}}c 1503<ref name="Agnes3" /> | England | Petronilla de Meath | First woman executed for witchcraft in England.<ref name="Agnes3" /><ref name="Waddell2003">{{cite book|author=Terrie Waddell|title=Cultural expressions of evil and wickedness: wrath, sex, crime|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EXPREjWLJgMC&pg=PA86|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=2003|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-420-1015-4|page=86}}</ref> |- | [[Agnodice]] | {{Hs|505}}c 505<ref name="C78" /> | Greece | Aspasia | First female gynecologist.<ref name="Oakes2007">{{cite book|author=Elizabeth H. Oakes|title=Encyclopedia of world scientists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uPRB-OED1bcC&pg=PA6|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=2007|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6158-7|page=6}}</ref> She disguised herself as a man in order to go to medical school. She became a gynecologist, and when male doctors realized women preferred her services, they charged her with malpractice. She outed herself, and they tried to pass a law prohibiting women to practice medicine. The law was eventually changed, due to women speaking out, in the twelfth century.<ref name="C78" /> |- | [[Agrippina the Elder|Agrippina I]] | {{Hs|-14}}c 14 BC<ref name="Agrippina1">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Agrippina I | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Agrippina I | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/agrippina_i.php | accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="Salisbury2001">{{cite book|author=Joyce E. Salisbury|title=Women in the ancient world|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HF0m3spOebcC&pg=PA3|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=2001|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-092-5|page=3}}</ref> | Rome | Marcella | Married [[Germanicus]] and accompanied him into battle during wartime. After his death, she became a voice representing the political struggle of Rome, and her and her two teenage sons were accused of trying to overthrow [[Tiberius]] and they were eventually exiled.<ref name="C146" /><ref name="Agrippina1" /> |- | [[Agrippina the Younger|Agrippina II]] | {{Hs|15}}15 | Rome | Marcella | Julia Agrippina, Roman noble woman, the wife of the emperor Claudius and mother of Nero, who effectively ruled the empire for two decades through her influence over both her husband and son. |- | [[Aisha (poet)|Aisha]] | {{Hs|1101}}12th century | Spain | Hrosvitha | Spanish poet who presented her work at the Royal Academy of [[Córdoba, Andalusia]].<ref name="C109" /> |- | [[Ajysyt]] | {{Hs|-10000}}Mythical | Siberia | Primordial Goddess | Siberian goddess of birth. A fertility deity of the Turkic [[Yakuts|Yakut]] people from the [[Lena River]] region of [[Siberia]]. The name means "birthgiver" and may also be called the "Mother of Cradles" <ref name="C36">Chicago, 36.</ref><ref name="Jordan2004">{{cite book|author=Michael Jordan|title=Dictionary of gods and goddesses|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aqDC5bwx4_wC&pg=PA10|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=August 2004|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-5923-2|page=10}}</ref> |- | [[Albertine Necker de Saussure]] | {{Hs|1766}}1766 | France | Emily Dickinson | Cousin of writer [[Germaine de Staël]],<ref name="Albertine">{{cite web | author= | year=2007 | title=Albertine Necker de Saussure | work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: The Dinner Party: Heritage Floor: Aleksandra Kollantay | publisher=Brooklyn Museum | url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/heritage_floor/aleksandra_kollantay.php | accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref> She fled Russia in 1905 and lived in Germany, advocating women's issues. Oakes|title=Encyclopedia of world scientists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uPRB-OED1bcC&pg=PA274|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=2007|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6158-7|page=274}}</ref> She was a medical illustrator and assistant to [[Mondino de Liuzzi]].<ref name="C145">Chicago, 145.</ref> |- | [[Aletta Jacobs]] | {{Hs|1854}}1854 | Netherlands | Susan B. Cornelia died in the same year of her brother's consulship; if this brother is identified as P. Cornelius Scipio, the date was 16 BC. Emperor Augustus, her stepfather, grieved her death as he found her a worthy elder sister to his daughter, Julia. The poet Propertius wrote an elegy of Cornelia for her funeral, praising her virtue and family, including Scipio and Scribonia. |- | [[Cornelia Africana|Cornelia Gracchi]] | 190 BC | Ancient Rome | Hypatia | Second daughter of Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus, the hero of the Second Punic War, and Aemilia Paulla.
