Now Rubio wants to take it national|last=Hall|first=Kevin|work=Miami Herald|access-date=July 31, 2018}} ==Personal life== [[File:Rubio Sworn In.jpg|thumb|Rubio, and wife Jeanette, just after being sworn as a [[List of current United States Senators|U.S. Senator]] by Vice President [[Joseph Biden|Joe Biden]]. January 2011]] Rubio married [[Jeanette Dousdebes Rubio|Jeanette Dousdebes]], a former bank teller and [[Miami Dolphins Cheerleaders|Miami Dolphins cheerleader]], in 1998 in a Catholic ceremony at the [[Church of the Little Flower (Coral Gables, Florida)|Church of the Little Flower]], and together they have four children.{{cite web |last=Rettig |first=Jessica |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2010/05/04/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-marco-rubio |title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Marco Rubio |work=U.S. News and World Report |date=May 4, 2010 |accessdate=February 14, 2013}}{{cite news |title=The women behind the men who would be Florida's senator |url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/national/the-women-behind-the-men-who-would-be-floridas-senator/1112189 |newspaper=Tampa Bay Times |date=July 31, 2010 |accessdate=February 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130424204219/http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/national/the-women-behind-the-men-who-would-be-floridas-senator/1112189 |archivedate=April 24, 2013 |df=mdy-all|last=Silva|first=Christina }} Rubio and his family live in [[West Miami, Florida]].{{cite web |url=http://www.myfloridahouse.gov/SEctions/Representatives/details.aspx?MemberId=4180&SessionId=42 |title=Representative Marco Rubio |publisher=Florida House of Representatives}} Rubio attends Catholic Mass at [[Church of the Little Flower (Coral Gables, Florida)|Church of the Little Flower]] in [[Coral Gables, Florida]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/27/us/27beliefs.html |title=Marco Rubio: Catholic or Protestant? |first=Mark |last=Oppenheimer |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 26, 2010}} He also previously attended [[Christ Fellowship]], a [[Southern Baptist]] Church{{cite web|url=http://www.sbc.net/churchsearch/church.asp?ID=2979-33157|title=Southern Baptist Convention|publisher=sbc.net}} in [[West Kendall, Florida]].{{cite news|title=Is Marco Rubio Catholic or Baptist? Or Is the Reformation Over? |url=http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/11/15/is-marco-rubio-catholic-or-baptist-or-is-the-reformation-over/print/ |work=Politics Daily |first=David |last=Gibson |date=November 15, 2010 |accessdate=February 14, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514074024/http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/11/15/is-marco-rubio-catholic-or-baptist-or-is-the-reformation-over/print/ |archivedate=May 14, 2014 }}/ {{Infobox person | name = Mary Adams | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- filename only, i.e. without "File:" (or "Image:") prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Mary Ritchie | birth_date = {{birth date|1922|11|3|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Montrose (Angus)|Montrose]], [[Scotland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2010|7|12|1922|11|3|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Dalgety Bay]], Scotland | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|Scottish]] | other_names = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[cryptanalysis|codebreaker]] | years_active = 1943–1947 | era = | employer = [[Foreign Office]] | organization = [[Government Code and Cypher School]] | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | boards = | spouse = Bob Adams | partner = | children = Bob, David, Lorna | parents = Maggie and John Ritchie | relatives = | callsign = | awards = Bletchly Park Commemorative Badge | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | ethnicity = | religion = | denomination = | box_width = }}
'''Mary Adams''' (née Ritchie) (3 November 1922 – 12 July 2010) was a Scottish interceptor for [[Bletchley Park]] during [[World War II]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/1313F1E4F1499978?p=UKNB|title=Mary Adams|last=Shaw|first=Alison|date=27 July 2010|work=The Herald (Glasgow)|access-date=19 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituary-mary-adams-1-817799|title=Mary Adams|last=|first=|date=18 July 2010|work=The Scotsman|access-date=19 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Adams was born in [[Montrose, Angus|Montrose]], Scotland to Maggie and John Ritchie. Her father was a railway foreman. Her parents moved to [[Stonehaven]] where she attended [[Mackie Academy]] before going on to take a job as a clerk in solicitors' office. In 1943 she signed up for the [[Auxiliary Territorial Service]] and was selected for the [[Royal Corps of Signals]], where she was trained in receiving [[Morse code]]. She was then assigned to Bletchley Park as an interceptor of German and Italian coded signals. Adams stated that she preferred to intercept Italian signals as Italians were often excitable when transmitting which lead them to make mistakes causing them to repeat their messages, and thereby giving her a second chance to capture their messages.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Having signed the Official Secrets Act, Adams did not talk to anyone, not even her husband, about her work during the war. When [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] officer [[F. W. Winterbotham|Frederick Winterbotham]] published his book ''The Ultra Secret'' in 1974, she then felt able to mention her work.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Adams married Bob Adams, an accountant, in 1950. They had three children, Bob, David and Lorna.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
After the war Adams trained as a [[radiographer]] at [[Manchester Royal Infirmary]]. After her children were born she worked as a volunteer at the [[Citizens Advice|Citizens' Advice Bureau]], going on to work as trainer and tutor at its Edinburgh offices.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
In 2009 Adams was presented with the Bletchley Park Commemorative Badge in recognition of her role during the war.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
In later life she suffered from [[Alzheimer's disease]] and was cared for at a nursing home. She died on 12 July 2010.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, Mary}} [[Category:Bletchley Park people]] [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Bletchley Park women]] [[Category:People from Montrose, Angus]]

{{other people5|Michael Bennett (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Michael Bennet |image = Michael Bennet Official Photo.jpg |jr/sr = United States Senator |state = [[Colorado]] |alongside = [[Cory Gardner]] |term_start = January 21, 2009 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Ken Salazar]] |appointer = [[Bill Ritter]] |office1 = Chair of the [[Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee]] |leader1 = [[Harry Reid]] |term_start1 = January 3, 2013 |term_end1 = January 3, 2015 |predecessor1 = [[Patty Murray]] |successor1 = [[Jon Tester]] |office2 = [[Superintendent (education)|Superintendent]] of [[Denver Public Schools]] |term_start2 = July 1, 2005 |term_end2 = January 21, 2009 |predecessor2 = Jerome Wartgow |successor2 = Tom Boasberg |birth_name = Michael Farrand Bennet |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|11|28}} |birth_place = [[New Delhi]], [[India]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = {{marriage|Susan Daggett|1997}} |children = 3 |education = [[Wesleyan University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[Yale University]] {{small|([[Juris Doctor|JD]])}} |website = {{url|https://bennet.senate.gov|Senate website}} }} '''Michael Farrand Bennet''' (born November 28, 1964) is an American businessman, lawyer and politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|senior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Colorado]], a seat he has held since 2009. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], he was appointed to the seat when [[Ken Salazar]] resigned to become [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]]. Bennet previously worked as managing director for the [[The Anschutz Corporation|Anschutz Investment Company]], chief of staff to then-[[Denver, Colorado|Denver]] Mayor (and current Colorado Governor) [[John Hickenlooper]], and superintendent of [[Denver Public Schools]]. Bennet is the son of [[Douglas J. Bennet]], a former [[United States Department of State|State Department]] official and president of [[Wesleyan University]]. Early in his career, Bennet worked for [[Governor of Ohio|Ohio Governor]] [[Richard Celeste]]. He went on to receive his [[Juris Doctor]] degree, after which he worked as a law clerk and later as Counsel to the [[United States Deputy Attorney General|U.S. Deputy Attorney General]] in the [[Presidency of Bill Clinton|Clinton Administration]]. Bennet became [[Superintendent (education)|superintendent]] of the Denver public school system in July 2005. Bennet was speculated in late 2008 as a candidate for Obama's [[United States Secretary of Education]]. He was appointed by Governor [[Bill Ritter]] to fill the U.S. Senate seat vacated by [[Ken Salazar]] when Salazar became [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]] in January 2009. Bennet was elected in the [[United States Senate election in Colorado, 2010|2010 Senate election]] where he defeated [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Ken Buck]]. He chaired the [[Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee]] (DSCC) for the [[United States Senate elections, 2014|2014 cycle]]John Bresnahan and Manu Raju, [http://www.politico.com/story/2012/12/michael-bennet-tapped-to-run-dscc-84568.html "Harry Reid taps Michael Bennet to run DSCC"], politico.com, December 4, 2012; accessed November 27, 2014. and was reelected in the [[United States Senate election in Colorado, 2016|2016 elections]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2016/11/08/michael-bennet-darryl-glenn-senate-election-results/|title=Michael Bennet defeats Darryl Glenn in Senate race in Colorado|date=2016-11-08|website=The Denver Post|access-date=2017-06-26}} ==Early life and education== He was born in [[New Delhi]] while his father, [[Douglas J. Bennet]], was serving as an aide to [[Chester Bowles]], then the U.S. [[United States Ambassador to India|ambassador]] to India. Douglas Bennet ran the [[United States Agency for International Development]] under President [[Jimmy Carter]],{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/01/15/070115fa_fact_boo|title=Expectations – Can the students who became a symbol of failed reform be rescued?|work=[[The New Yorker]]|first=Katherine|last=Boo|date=January 15, 2007|accessdate=January 3, 2009}} served as President and CEO of [[National Public Radio]] (1983–93), and [[Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs]] in the Clinton Administration (1993–95). His grandfather, Douglas Bennet, had been an economic adviser in [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]'s administration. Bennet's mother, Susanne Christine (née Klejman),{{citation|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/senators/bennet.htm|title=Ancestry of Michael Bennet|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} immigrated to the United States with her family in 1950. Her parents were [[Polish Jews]] and survived imprisonment in the [[Warsaw Ghetto]].{{cite news|last=Mitchell|first=Nancy|title=Bennet's tale steeped in family roots|publisher=Rocky Mountain News|date=January 24, 2009|url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2009/jan/24/american-tale/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301050159/http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2009/jan/24/american-tale/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 1, 2009|accessdate=August 5, 2016}} Bennet's mother is a retired elementary school librarian.{{cite news|first=Nancy|last=Mitchell|title=Heading back to the Beltway|date=January 3, 2009|url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2009/jan/03/heading-back-to-the-beltway/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303003526/http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2009/jan/03/heading-back-to-the-beltway/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 3, 2009|work=[[Rocky Mountain News]]|accessdate=August 5, 2016}} Bennet grew up in [[Washington, D.C.]] as his father served as an aide to Vice President [[Hubert Humphrey]], among others. Bennet was held back in second grade because of his struggle with [[dyslexia]].{{cite news|first=Nancy|last=Mitchell|title=One finalist enough for DPS board|date=January 9, 2009|url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2009/jan/09/one-finalist-enough-for-dps-board/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303004038/http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2009/jan/09/one-finalist-enough-for-dps-board/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 3, 2009|work=Rocky Mountain News|accessdate=August 5, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/articles/news/politics/2010/06/14/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-michael-bennet.html|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Michael Bennet|publisher=Usnews.com|date=June 14, 2010|accessdate=August 29, 2010}} He was enrolled at [[St. Albans School (Washington, D.C.)|St. Albans School]], an elite all-boys [[University-preparatory school|preparatory school]], and served as a [[United States Senate Page|page]] on [[Capitol Hill]].{{cite news | first=Kevin|last=Vaughan|title=Michael Bennet followed his heart to the mayor's office|date=November 29, 2008| url=http://m.rockymountainnews.com/news/2003/Nov/29/barchiveb-the-path-to-public-service/| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106041515/http://m.rockymountainnews.com/news/2003/Nov/29/barchiveb-the-path-to-public-service/| dead-url=yes| archive-date=January 6, 2014|work=[[Rocky Mountain News]]|accessdate=January 3, 2009}} In 1987, Bennet earned his [[Bachelors of Arts|B.A.]] degree in history from [[Wesleyan University]],{{cite web|url=http://www.wesleyan.edu/about/alumni.html|title=Notable Alumni, About - Wesleyan University|website=www.wesleyan.edu}} the alma mater of his father and grandfather.{{cite news|last1=Pearlstein|first1=Steven|title=The can-do senator in a can't-do Congress|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/the-can-do-senator-in-a-cant-do-congress/2016/06/14/b58ccd78-1953-11e6-9e16-2e5a123aac62_story.html|accessdate=25 July 2016|publisher=Washington Post|date=16 June 2016}} At Wesleyan, Bennet was a member of [[Beta Theta Pi]]. Bennet earned his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from [[Yale Law School]], where he was the Editor-in-Chief of the ''[[Yale Law Journal]]''.{{cite news|last1=Lach|first1=Eric|title=Michael Bennet: From Superintendent to Colorado Senator|url=http://www.newyorker.com/the-new-yorker-blog/michael-bennet-from-superintendent-to-colorado-senator|accessdate=5 August 2016|publisher=The New Yorker|date=January 2, 2009}} ==Career before U.S. Senate== From 1988 until 1990, when he left to attend Yale, he served as an aide to [[Governor of Ohio|Ohio Governor]] [[Richard Celeste]]. After law school he served as a law clerk for the [[4th Circuit Court of Appeals]]{{dead link|date=August 2016}} and as an associate to [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] attorney [[Lloyd Cutler]]. He then served as Counsel to the [[United States Deputy Attorney General|Deputy Attorney General]] during [[Bill Clinton]]'s [[Presidency of Bill Clinton|administration]].{{cite news|work=Denver Public Schools Communications Office |title=Michael F. Bennet biography |url=http://communications.dpsk12.org/newsroom/353/224 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022084212/http://communications.dpsk12.org/newsroom/353/224/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 22, 2008 |df= }} Douglas Bennet worked in the Clinton White House as well, as [[Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs]]. Following a stint as an assistant to the U.S. attorney in Connecticut, Bennet left the legal world and moved West. After briefly living in [[Montana]], Bennet moved with his fiancé to Colorado in 1997.{{cite news|last1=Booth|first1=Michael|title=Bennet's storied career is marked by adaptability|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2010/09/25/bennets-storied-career-is-marked-by-adaptability/|accessdate=25 July 2016|publisher=Denver Post|date=25 September 2010}} Bennett worked for six years in [[Denver]] as Managing Director for the [[The Anschutz Corporation|Anschutz Investment Company]], where he led the reorganization of an oil company and helped consolidate three movie theater chains into the [[Regal Entertainment Group]].{{cite news|last1=Lane|first1=Anthony|title=The accidental senator|url=http://www.csindy.com/coloradosprings/the-accidental-senator/Content?oid=1358636|accessdate=3 August 2016|publisher=Colorado Springs Independent|date=May 14, 2009}}{{cite news|last1=Doyle|first1=Patrick|title=The Accidental Senator|url=http://www.5280.com/news/politics/magazine/2015/04/accidental-senator?page=full|accessdate=3 August 2016|publisher=5280|date=May 2015}} While working for Anschutz, Bennet befriended fellow Wesleyan alumnus [[John Hickenlooper]], informally advising the latter's successful campaign for [[List of mayors of Denver|Mayor of Denver]]. Moving back into public service, Bennet served for two years as Hickenlooper's Chief of Staff. Bennet was appointed [[Superintendent (education)|superintendent]] of [[Denver Public Schools]] on June 27, 2005, taking office on the following July 1. Bennet had no experience as a school administrator. In 2008, Bennet persuaded the Denver Board of Education to enter into a 30-year, $750 million financial bond transaction with variable interest rates designed to fluctuate as economic conditions changed. ''The New York Times'' wrote that "In short order, the transaction went awry because of stress in the credit markets, problems with the bond insurer and plummeting interest rates." As of 2010, the school system had paid $115 million in interest and other fees, at least $25 million more than it originally anticipated.{{cite news|last1=Morgensen|first1=Gretchen|title=Exotic Deals Put Denver Schools Deeper in Debt|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/06/business/06denver.html|accessdate=3 August 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=August 5, 2010}} Bennet was among the many officials whose names were circulated for [[United States Secretary of Education]] in the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama Administration]], which was eventually filled by [[Arne Duncan]].{{cite news|title=Bennet confirms he won't be Obama's education secretary |date=December 15, 2008 |url=http://www.denverpost.com/education/ci_11238729 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131212728/http://www.denverpost.com/education/ci_11238729 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 31, 2009 |work=Denver Post |accessdate=January 2, 2009 |df= }} Bennet and his wife were early supporters of [[Barack Obama]]'s presidential bid during the [[2008 Democratic primaries]]{{cite news|title=Obama visits Denver |date=January 30, 2008 |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jan/30/obama-denver-live-coverage |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080201060809/http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jan/30/obama-denver-live-coverage/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 1, 2008 |work=[[Rocky Mountain News]] |accessdate=January 2, 2009 |df= }} and he was among those who advised Barack Obama on education issues.{{cite news|first=Kirsten |last=Wyatt |title=Colo.'s new senator relatively unknown to voters |date=January 6, 2009 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gy7TzJdJiC2coP1n-vDJgbgI7uFwD95HJ8TO0 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131095146/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gy7TzJdJiC2coP1n-vDJgbgI7uFwD95HJ8TO0 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 31, 2009 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=January 7, 2009 |df= }} ==U.S. Senate== ===Appointment=== On January 3, 2009, he was named by [[Governor of Colorado|Colorado Governor]] [[Bill Ritter]] to fill the seat in the [[United States Senate]] vacated by [[United States Secretary of the Interior]] [[Ken Salazar]] on January 20.{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.gov/cs/Satellite?c=Page&cid=1230985756099&pagename=GovRitter%2FGOVRLayout |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131134816/http://www.colorado.gov/cs/Satellite?c=Page&cid=1230985756099&pagename=GovRitter%2FGOVRLayout |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 31, 2009 |title=Official press release from Governor Bill Ritter on appointment of Michael Bennet |publisher=Colorado.gov |date=January 3, 2009 |accessdate=November 1, 2010 |df= }} Ritter chose Bennet after interviewing several prominent Colorado Democrats, and Bennet took the job with the blessing of Hickenlooper. Upon taking office on January 21, 2009, he stated that he would seek [[United States Senate election in Colorado, 2010|election]] at the end of his term in 2010.{{cite news | first=Karen | last=Crummy | title=Michael Bennet chosen as next Senator | date=January 2, 2009 | url=http://www.denverpost.com/breakingnews/ci_11355396 |work=Denver Post | accessdate=January 2, 2009}}{{Failed verification|date=November 2010}} In a January 2011 article in ''Time'' entitled "Shaking Schools Up in an Already Tumultuous Year," the author of the article, Andrew J. Rotherham, said of Bennet: "If the federal [[No Child Left Behind Act]] is modified this year, or if anything else of significance happens in Washington on education policy, this Colorado Democrat will be at the center of it."{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2040867_2040871_2040874,00.html | work=Time | title=School Of Thought: 11 Education Activists For 2011 | date=January 6, 2011}} ===2010 election=== [[File:CO2010c3.png|thumb|right|County results of the race]] {{Main|United States Senate election in Colorado, 2010}} Bennet ran for election for a full term as Senator from Colorado in the 2010 election.{{dead link|date=August 2016}} On September 16, 2009, former [[Colorado House of Representatives|Colorado House]] [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] [[Andrew Romanoff]] announced his campaign to challenge Bennet for the Democratic nomination.{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_13353969 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914075440/http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_13353969 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 14, 2010 |title=Sources: Romanoff launches Senate bid: "Colorado is my cause" |work=Denver Post |accessdate=September 18, 2009 |first=Lynn |last=Bartels |date=September 17, 2009 |df= }} Bennet received endorsements from President [[Barack Obama]], U.S. Senator [[Mark Udall]], and U.S. Representatives [[Betsy Markey]], [[Jared Polis]], and [[John Salazar]] of the Colorado congressional delegation.{{cite news|last=Riley |first=Michael |url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_13325723 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914061249/http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_13325723 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 14, 2009 |title=Rival Colorado Democrats play game of one-upmanship |publisher=The Denver Post |date=September 13, 2009 |accessdate=November 1, 2010 |df= }} Bennet raised $7 million and had a four-to-one cash advantage over his opponent, Andrew Romanoff.{{cite news|last1=Catanese|first1=David|title=How Michael Bennet made it look easy|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0810/40971.html|accessdate=13 August 2014|publisher=Politico|date=11 August 2010}} On August 10, 2010, Bennet defeated Romanoff in the [[primary election|primary]] and won his party's nomination,{{cite news|last=Brown |first=Jennifer |url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_15735379 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815234200/http://www.denverpost.com/ci_15735379 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 15, 2010 |title=Bennet Wins, Buck Leads |publisher=The Denver Post |date=August 10, 2010 |accessdate=November 1, 2010 |df= }} facing Republican candidate [[Ken Buck]]. The campaign became one of the most expensive in the country, with the candidates spending a reported $15 million combined, and outside groups another $30 million. Bennet portrayed Buck as an extremist conservative opposed to [[abortion]] and [[direct election]] of Senators, while Buck and the groups supporting him characterized Bennet as a big-spending liberal.{{cite news | first = Jeff | last = Brady | title = Money Has Poured Into Colorado's Senate Race | date = October 27, 2010 | url = https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130864318 | work = NPR | accessdate = October 29, 2010}} After Bennet won election, President Obama said Bennet "perfectly reflects the qualities of the ruggedly independent state he has been chosen to serve."{{cite news|title=Obama praises new Colorado senator, Michael Bennet|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/01/03/obama-praises-new-colorado-sen-bennet/|accessdate=31 October 2014|publisher=CNN|date=3 January 2009}} On November 3, the day after polls closed, Bennet was declared the winner and Buck conceded. Bennet won by 851,590 votes (48.1%) to 822,731 (46.4%). He subsequently returned to Washington in January 2011 to start a full six-year term. ===2016 election=== [[File:Colorado Senate Election Results by County, 2016.svg|thumb|right|County results of the race]] Bennet was re-elected to a second term on November 8, 2016. He defeated Republican Candidate and El Paso County Commissioner Darryl Glenn. Bennet received 1.36 million votes, 156,248 more than Glenn. He received 31,780 more votes than Democratic presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]], who also won the state in the [[United States elections, 2016|general election]]. Bennet received more votes than any other Democrat in a statewide race in Colorado history. He also won more votes in Colorado's rural counties than any other statewide Democrat in state history. Following the election, [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] said Bennet was one of the "gifted Democratic politicians" that could lead the party in the future.Remnick, David (28 November 2016). "[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/11/28/obama-reckons-with-a-trump-presidency Obama Reckons with a Trump Presidency]." ''New Yorker''"[https://art19.com/shows/pod-save-america/episodes/d2db83ae-1d0f-4546-ac88-6db54e32bec3/embed?theme=dark-blue Obama's Last Interview]," Pod Save America (19 January 2017). ===Committee assignments=== Bennet sits on the following committees and subcommittees in the [[115th United States Congress]] (2017–2019). * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry|Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry]]''' **[[United States Senate Agriculture Subcommittee on Commodities, Markets, Trade and Risk Management|Subcommittee on Commodities, Markets, Trade and Risk Management]] **[[United States Senate Agriculture Subcommittee on Conservation, Forestry and Natural Resources|Subcommittee on Conservation, Forestry and Natural Resources]] (Ranking Member) **[[United States Senate Agriculture Subcommittee on Nutrition, Agricultural Research and Specialty Crops|Subcommittee on Nutrition, Agricultural Research and Specialty Crops]] **[[United States Senate Agriculture Subcommittee on Rural Development and Energy|Subcommittee on Rural Development and Energy]] * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Finance|Committee on Finance]]''' **[[United States Senate Finance Subcommittee on Energy, Natural Resources, and Infrastructure|Subcommittee on Energy, Natural Resources, and Infrastructure]] (Ranking Member) **[[United States Senate Finance Subcommittee on Taxation and IRS Oversight|Subcommittee on Taxation and IRS Oversight]] * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions|Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions]]''' ** [[United States Senate Health Subcommittee on Children and Families|Subcommittee on Children and Families]] ** [[United States Senate Health Subcommittee on Primary Health and Retirement Security|Subcommittee on Primary Health and Retirement Security]] Source: [[United States Senate]]{{cite web|title=Committee Assignments of the 113th Congress |url=https://www.senate.gov/general/committee_assignments/assignments.htm |publisher=United States Senate |accessdate=March 7, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170218025059/https://www.senate.gov/general/committee_assignments/assignments.htm |archivedate=February 18, 2017 |df= }} ==Political positions== [[File:MichaelBennetofficialphoto.jpg|thumb|right|Senator Michael Bennet]] ===Gun law=== As of 2010, Bennet had earned a "C+" rating from the [[National Rifle Association]] for a mixed record regarding his votes for [[Gun politics in the United States|gun rights]].{{cite web|title=Michael Bennet on Gun Control|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Domestic/Michael_Bennet_Gun_Control.htm|website=On The Issues|accessdate=4 October 2017}} In 2012, Bennet joined then Colorado Senator [[Mark Udall]] in asking for stricter gun control, in response to the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]]. In response to the shooting, Bennet stated that "In Colorado, we support the 2nd Amendment right to bear arms, we support the ability of people to hunt and recreate and to protect their families and homes, and we want to keep the wrong weapons out of the hands of the wrong people."{{cite web|title=Sens. Mark Udall, Michael Bennet Call For Stricter Gun Control Laws|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/21/sens-mark-udall-michael-b_n_2345493.html|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=4 October 2017|date=21 December 2012}} Bennet participated in the [[Chris Murphy gun control filibuster]], demanding that gun laws be changed in the wake of the [[Orlando nightclub shooting]]. During his participation in the filibuster, Bennet talked about the [[2012 Aurora shooting]], citing that as a response to the shooting, the state of Colorado closed gun sale loopholes and now requires background checks for any gun purchase.{{cite web|last1=Associated Press|title=Michael Bennet joins Senate filibuster over gun violence|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2016/06/15/michael-bennet-joins-senate-filibuster-over-gun-violence/|website=The Denver Post|accessdate=4 October 2017|date=16 June 2016}} In response to the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]], Bennet demanded [[universal background checks]] regarding gun sales and described the shooting as [[domestic terrorism]].{{cite web|last1=Clark|first1=Kyle|title=Debating the definition of 'terrorism' after the Las Vegas shooting|url=http://www.9news.com/news/local/next/debating-the-definition-of-terrorism-after-the-las-vegas-shooting/480668441|website=KUSA|accessdate=4 October 2017}} ===Health care policy=== Bennet voted in support of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] signed by President [[Barack Obama]] on March 23, 2010. In November 2009, when the bill was still working its way through Congress, Bennet said that he would support [[health care]] reform even if it meant losing the election.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/11/22/michael-bennet-ill-lose-m_n_366780.html|title=Sources: Michael Bennet: I'll Lose My Seat To Support Health Care (VIDEO)|work=Huffington Post |accessdate=January 6, 2011|first=Sam|last=Stein|date=November 22, 2009}} In 2016, in response to healthcare costs in western and central Colorado, which has some of the highest healthcare costs in the United States, Bennet said he "didn't have answers" and called it "next to impossible" to fix the Affordable Care Act given partisan attitudes at that time.{{cite news|last1=Harmon|first1=Gary|title=Sen. Bennet sheds light on local issues in GJ visit|url=http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/articles/sen-bennet-knows-our-issues-has-no-answers|accessdate=8 August 2016|publisher=The Daily Sentinel|date=May 6, 2016}} As part of a group of Democrats proposing "more incremental steps to broaden health care coverage", as opposed to [[Bernie Sanders]]'s push of "Medicare for All", Senator [[Tim Kaine]] and Michael Bennet have proposed "Medicare X". Medicare X would "create a public option modeled after [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] alongside private options on the [[ObamaCare]] [[Health insurance marketplace|marketplaces]]".{{cite web|last1=Sullivan|first1=Peter|title=Democrats march toward single-payer health care|url=http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/375376-democrats-march-toward-single-payer-health-care|website=The Hill|accessdate=25 February 2018}} ===Immigration policy=== In September 2009, Bennet cosponsored the [[DREAM Act]] (S. 729), which proposed amending the [[Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996]] by giving residency to immigrants enrolled in higher education programs or serving in the military.{{cite news|last1=Rosa|first1=Erin|title=Bennet on the record: Supports DREAM Act for immigration reform|url=http://www.coloradoindependent.com/25564/bennet-on-the-record-supports-dream-act-for-immigration-reform|accessdate=8 August 2016|publisher=Colorado Independent|date=April 3, 2009}} In 2013, Bennet was a member of the [[Gang of Eight (immigration)|Gang of Eight]], a bipartisan group of four Democratic and four Republican U.S. Senators who introduced comprehensive [[immigration reform]] legislation.{{cite web |title=Senators Reach a Bipartisan Agreement for Comprehensive Immigration Reform|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/senators-reach-bipartisan-agreement-comprehensive-immigration-reform| publisher=Fowler White Boggs P.A. |work=The National Law Review |date=January 31, 2013|accessdate=February 1, 2013}} Their bill, the [[Border Security, Economic Opportunity, and Immigration Modernization Act of 2013]], passed the U.S. Senate with a vote of 68-32, but stalled in the House due to opposition from the Republican majority.{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-bill/744|title=S.744 - Border Security, Economic Opportunity, and Immigration Modernization Act|last=|first=|date=|website=Congress.gov|access-date=26 June 2017}} ===Energy policy=== In 2009, Bennet co-sponsored the Solar Manufacturing Jobs Creation Act, legislation that would have provided a tax credit to support solar manufacturing in the U.S.{{cite news|title=Senators Introduce Solar Manufacturing Jobs Creation Act|url=http://solarindustrymag.com/senators-introduce-solar-manufacturing-jobs-creation-act|accessdate=8 August 2016|publisher=Solar Industry Magazine|date=November 11, 2009}} The legislation was not enacted.{{cite web|title=S. 2755 (111th): Solar Manufacturing Jobs Creation Act|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/111/s2755|publisher=GovTrack.us|accessdate=8 August 2016}} He was one of the handful of Democratic Senators who have supported construction of the [[Keystone Pipeline|Keystone XL pipeline]], voting for it in 2013,{{cite web |url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/thespot/2013/03/25/bennet-says-yes-udall-says-no-in-split-vote-on-keystone-pipeline/93099/ |title=Bennet Says Yes, Udall Says No, In Split Vote On Keystone |last=Sherry |first=Allison |date=25 March 2013 |website=Denver Post |access-date=5 March 2015}} 2014,{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/11/michael-bennet-brings-senates-pro-keystone-count-to-59-112906.html |title=Michael Bennet Brings Senate's Pro-Keystone Count to 59 |last=Schor |first=Elana |date=14 November 2014 |website=Politico |access-date=5 March 2015}} and 2015.{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/234615-senate-fails-to-override-obama-keystone-veto |title=Keystone Veto Override Fails |last=Barron-Lopez |first=Laura |date=4 March 2015 |website=The Hill |access-date=5 March 2015}} ===Cannabis=== Bennet has cosponsored the bipartisan [[STATES Act]] proposed in the [[115th United States Congress|115th U.S. Congress]] by [[List of United States Senators from Massachusetts|Massachusetts Senator]] [[Elizabeth Warren]] and fellow [[List of United States Senators from Colorado|Colorado Senator]] [[Cory Gardner]] that would exempt individuals or corporations in compliance with state cannabis laws from federal enforcement of the [[Controlled Substances Act]].{{cite web|title=Cosponsors - S.3032 - 115th Congress (2017-2018): STATES Act|website=www.congress.gov|access-date=July 7, 2018|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/3032/cosponsors}} ==Personal life== On October 26, 1997, he married [[Earthjustice]] Legal Defense Fund attorney Susan Diane Daggett, in [[Marianna, Arkansas]].{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS; Susan Daggett, Michael Bennet|date=October 26, 1997|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9906E1D6133EF935A15753C1A961958260|work=New York Times|accessdate=January 3, 2009}} They have three daughters and reside in [[Denver]]'s [[Congress Park, Denver|Congress Park]] neighborhood.{{cite news|first=Christopher N. |last=Osher |title=Sources: Salazar accepts Interior post |date=December 16, 2008 |url=http://www.denverpost.com/localpolitics/ci_11240669 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090111011619/http://www.denverpost.com/localpolitics/ci_11240669 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 11, 2009 |work=Denver Post |accessdate=January 3, 2009 |df= }} Though not raised in an observant household, Bennet acknowledges his family's Jewish roots.[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/biography/Michael_Bennet.html American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise: Jewish Virtual Library entry on Michael Bennet] Retrieved December 25, 2011[http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/national/colorado_primary_two_jewish_democrats_square_special_interests The New York Jewish Week: "In Colorado Primary, Two Jewish Democrats Square Off on Special Interests"] July 13, 2010[http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/58919/in-races-for-congress-some-jewish-incumbents-at-risk/ Jewish News Weekly of Northern California: "In races for Congress, some Jewish incumbents at risk"] August 12, 2010 Bennet has stated that he was "raised with two different heritages, one [that] was [[Jewish]] and one [that] was [[Christian]]," and that he believes in God. His brother, [[James Bennet (journalist)|James Bennet]], is the editorial page director for ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news | first=Kate | last=Phillips | title=Denver Schools Chief Said to Replace Salazar in Senate | date=January 2, 2009 | url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/02/denver-schools-chief-said-to-replace-salazar-in-senate/?hp |work=New York Times | accessdate=January 2, 2009}} == Electoral history == {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="4" |United States Senate Democratic primary election in Colorado, 2010 |- |'''Party''' |'''Candidate''' |'''Votes''' |'''%''' |- |'''Democratic''' |'''Michael Bennet''' |'''184,714''' |'''54.15''' |- |Democratic |Andrew Romanoff |156,419 |45.85 |} {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="4" |United States Senate election in Colorado, 2010 |- |'''Party''' |'''Candidate''' |'''Votes''' |'''%''' |- |'''Democratic''' |'''Michael Bennet''' |'''854,685''' |'''48.08''' |- |Republican |Ken Buck |824,789 |46.40 |- |Green |Bob Kinsey |38,884 |2.19 |- |Libertarian |Maclyn Stringer |22,646 |1.27 |- |Independent Reform |Jason Napolitano |19,450 |1.09 |- |Independent |Charley Miller |11,351 |0.64 |- |Independent |J. Moromisato |5,780 |0.03 |- |Republican (write-in) |Robert Rank |52 |0.00 |- |Independent (write-in) |Michele Newman |20 |0.00 |- |Green (write-in) |Bruce Lohmiller |11 |0.00 |} {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="4" |United States Senate election in Colorado, 2016{{Cite web|url=http://results.enr.clarityelections.com/CO/63746/184388/Web01/en/summary.html|title=Colorado Secretary of State - 2016 Election Results|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} |- |'''Party''' |'''Candidate''' |'''Votes''' |'''%''' |- |'''Democratic''' |'''Michael Bennet''' |'''1,370,710''' |'''49.97''' |- |Republican |Darryl Glenn |1,215,318 |44.31 |- |Libertarian |Lily Tang Williams |99,277 |3.62 |- |Green |Arn Menconi |36,805 |1.34 |- |Others | |20,913 |0.76 |} ==See also== *[[List of United States Senators born outside the United States]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://bennet.senate.gov/ Senator Michael F. revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Lebanese physician" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Lebanese physician}} [[File:Michael Shadid.jpg|thumb|right|Michael Shadid]] '''Dr. Michael Abraham Shadid''' (1882 – August 13, 1966) was a [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] physician who founded the first medical [[cooperative]] in [[Elk City, Oklahoma]] in 1931.<ref name="time">{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,761173-1,00.html|title=Medicine: Cooperative Doctor|publisher=[[Time Magazine]]| date=1939-05-01 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> He was the first president of the Cooperative Health Federation of America and an advocate for cooperative health care and preventive medicine.
==Early life== Shadid was born in 1882 in [[Marjayoun]], [[Lebanon]], the youngest of 12 children. He attended the [[American University of Beirut|American University's]] high school in Beirut and in 1898 immigrated to the United States where he was a pack peddler and sold cheap jewelry and buttons door to door. Shadid attended [[Tarleton State University|John Tarleton College]] in [[Stephenville, Texas]] in 1902 and received a degree in medicine from [[Washington University in St. Louis]] in 1907. While in medical school, Shadid joined the [[Socialist Party of America]]. He ran for Congress as a [[New Deal coalition|New Deal democrat]] but was defeated by [[Sam Massingale]]. He married Adeeba Shadid and they had six children: Bess, Fred, Ethel, Alexander, Ruth, and Helen.<ref name="time"/>
==Career== In 1923, Shadid left a successful practice in [[Carter, Oklahoma]] and settled in Elk City. He found that farmers of the region were not receiving adequate medical care and did not have a hospital they could afford. Shadid called a meeting of his farmer patients and proposed a cooperatively owned clinic and hospital in Elk City. The Oklahoma Farmers' Union supported the measure and the hospital was opened by the Community Health Association, Inc. in August 1931. The reception from the medical community was icy. Although he had been a member of the Beckham County Medical Society for over 20 years, the society expelled him. The Oklahoma Board of Medical Examiners attempted to revoke Shadid's license and the State Medical Association tried to get a bill passed against medical cooperatives in the Oklahoma Legislature. The bill was defeated with the help of the Oklahoma Farmers' Union.<ref name="time"/> The Farmers' Union took control of the hospital and the health plan in 1934. By 1939, Community Hospital served 15,000 farmers in the southwestern Oklahoma. During the later years of his life, Dr. Shadid suffered from diabetes, resulting in having both legs amputated. With both legs missing, Dr. Shadid traveled to Russia alone in a wheel chair to speak about socialized medicine.(Authority: first-hand knowledge of Dr. Shadid's grand-daughter, S. Candice Campbell, whose mother was Bess Campbell, Dr. Shadid's daughter.)
==Later life== Shadid traveled throughout the United States and Europe and gave speeches where he advocated for cooperative health care. He helped launch a health co-op in [[Deer Park, Washington]] and assisted the organizing committee that led to the formation of [[Group Health Cooperative]].<ref>[http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&file_id=7411 Health care reformer Dr. Michael Shadid speaks to future founders of Group Health Cooperative in Seattle on August 14, 1945.] ''History Link.'' 9 August 2005.</ref> Shadid helped found the Cooperative Health Federation of America in 1947. He served as the Foundation's president from 1947 to 1949. In 1960 he built Hospital Haramoon in the Lebanese village where he was born. Shadid died in Kansas on August 13, 1966 and is buried in Oklahoma City at Fairlawn Cemetery.<ref>Huls, Glenna L. [http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/S/SH001.html Shadid, Michael Abraham (1882-1966).] ''Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History & Culture.''</ref> He was inducted into the [[Cooperative Development Foundation]]'s Cooperative Hall of Fame in 1978.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heroes.coop/inductees/shadid.html|title=Michael Shadid, M.D. (1882–1966)|publisher=Cooperative Hall of Fame}}</ref>
==Bibliography== *{{cite book |first= |last= |authorlink=Michael Shadid |coauthors= |title=The Self-Physician: Or How to Get Well and Keep Well |origyear= |month= |url= |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |date= |year=1912 |publisher=Oklahoma Pioneer |location=[[Oklahoma City]] |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= }} *{{cite book |first= |last= |authorlink=Michael Shadid |coauthors= |title=A doctor for the people; the autobiography of the founder of America’s first co-operative hospital |origyear= |month= |url=http://lccn.loc.gov/39027470 |format=autobiography |accessdate=2010-03-04 |edition= |series= |date= |year=1939 |publisher=The Vanguard press |location=[[New York City|New York]] |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= }} *{{cite book |first= |last= |authorlink=Michael Shadid |coauthors= |title=Doctors of today and tomorrow ... |origyear= |month= |url=http://lccn.loc.gov/med47000058 |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |date= |year=1947 |publisher=Cooperative League of the U.S.A. |location=[[New York City|New York]] |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= }} *{{cite book |first= |last= |authorlink=Michael Shadid |coauthors= |title=Crusading Doctor: My Fight for Cooperative Medicine |origyear= |month= |url=http://lccn.loc.gov/56001870 |format= |accessdate=2010-03-04 |edition= |series= |date= |year=1956 |publisher=Meador Publishing Company |location=[[Boston, Massachusetts]] |language= |isbn=0-8061-2344-3 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= }} *Michael A. Shadid Papers, Western History Collections, University of Oklahoma, Norman, Oklahoma. *Michael A. Shadid's grand daughters, E. Joy Murrell, of Austin, TX; Candice Campbell, M.S., L.P.C., of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shadid, Michael}} [[Category:Physicians from Oklahoma]] [[Category:Cooperative organisers]] [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1966 deaths]] [[Category:Lebanese people]]

revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=February 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Philip Serrell | image = Pswiki.jpg | caption = Philip Serrell during Antiques Road Trip filming. | birth_name = Philip Martyn Serrell | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1954|3|27}} | birth_place = [[Kidderminster]], [[Worcestershire]], England | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Auction]]eer | salary = | spouse =Briony Serrell | children =Clementine Serrell | website = [http://www.serrell.com/default.asp Official site] | imagesize = 200px | networth = }}
'''Philip Martyn Serrell''' (born 27 March 1954)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.duedil.com/director/905387345/philip-martyn-serrell/directorships|title=Duedil|publisher=|accessdate=7 January 2017}}</ref> is an English [[auctioneer]], [[antique]]s [[expert]] and [[television presenter]]. He has become a familiar face, especially on various BBC TV antiques programmes.
==Early life== Serrell was born in [[Kidderminster]], [[Worcestershire]] and attended the [[Royal Grammar School Worcester|Royal Grammar School]] in [[Worcester]], where he was a schoolmate of the [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistani]] [[cricket]] captain [[Imran Khan]]. Serrell played both cricket and [[Rugby union|rugby]] for the school, prior to his attendance at, and graduation from, [[Loughborough University|Loughborough College of Physical Education]] as a [[physical education]] [[teacher]].<ref name=BBCBio>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/profiles/skxZlpjX7QvL3JcwnJPmjd/philip-serrell|title=Flog It! - Philip Serrell - BBC One|publisher=|accessdate=7 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.speakingvolumes.co.uk/3_3_artists.php |title= Speaking Volumes|accessdate=2007-07-24 |format= |work= |publisher=The Swan Theater }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thespeakersagency.com/speakerdetail.asp?speaker=388&show=image |title=Philip Serrell |accessdate=2007-07-24 |format= |work= |publisher=The Speakers Agency |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929184452/http://www.thespeakersagency.com/speakerdetail.asp?speaker=388&show=image <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-29}}</ref>
==Career== Dissatisfied as a teacher, Serrell changed careers to become an [[auction]]eer, working in the local [[livestock]] trade until qualifying as a [[Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors|Chartered Surveyor]] in 1988, specialising in [[fine art]] and [[antique]]s.<ref name=BBCBio/>
Serrell owns an auctioneers and valuers firm with offices in [[Worcester]] and a salesroom in [[Great Malvern]], established in 1995.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.serrell.com/History.asp |title=Our History |accessdate=2007-07-20}}</ref> He is a regular expert on the [[BBC]] series ''[[Bargain Hunt]]'' and ''[[Flog It!]]'' and has also made a couple of appearances on [[ITV Network|ITV]]'s ''[[Dickinson's Real Deal]]''. He has also featured on other BBC series ''[[Antiques Road Trip]]'' and ''[[Put Your Money Where Your Mouth Is (TV series)|Put Your Money Where Your Mouth Is]]'' (where he is light-heartedly billed as Phil "The Fox" Serrell).
He has regularly appeared on [[BBC Hereford and Worcester|BBC Local Radio]], and has also written a biweekly [[newspaper column|column]] for the ''[[Worcester News]]''.
==Personal life== Married, he lives in Worcester with his wife. Serrell is an avid collector, living in a "house full of tat". He is a fan of [[Aston Martin]] cars and is a supporter of [[Worcester Warriors]] rugby team.
==Music career== In 2017, Serrell embarked on a music career with fellow BBC Antique Experts Charles Hanson, Charlie Ross and James Braxton by recording a Rock version of the classic "[[Sleigh Ride]]" in aid of [[Children in Need|BBC Children In Need]]. It was released digitally on independent record label Saga Entertainment and peaked at number 1 on the Amazon Rock Charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.radiotimes.com/news/tv/2017-12-01/the-bbcs-antiques-experts-unite-to-release-a-christmas-single/|title=The BBC’s antiques experts unite to release a Christmas single|publisher=|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/5038604/bbc-antiques-experts-to-release-christmas-single-in-aid-of-bbc-children-in-need/|title=BBC antiques experts to release Christmas single in aid of BBC Children in Need|date=1 December 2017|publisher=|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/4DqldYKs1YZPxYS1JYWtDjB/bbc-antiques-experts-have-swapped-their-auction-house-gavels-for-microphones-to-produce-a-christmas-single-in-aid-of-bbc-children-in-need|title=BBC Children in Need - BBC antiques experts have swapped their auction house gavels for microphones to produce a Christmas single in aid of BBC Children in Need|website=BBC|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref>
==Published works== *''An Auctioneer's Lot'' ({{ISBN|0340838957}}) *''Sold to the Man with the Tin Leg'' ({{ISBN|0340895020}})
==References== {{cite press release | title =Philip Serrell |url=http://www.serrell.com/History.asp| publisher = Philip Serrell | accessdate = 2007-07-19}} {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Philip Serrell}} *{{IMDb name|1060556}} *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006mk0g/profiles/philip-serrell BBC Bio] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050314231719/http://www.bbc.co.uk/communicate/archive/bargain_hunt/page3.shtml Interview] at [[BBC]] website
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Serrell, Philip}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Antiques experts]] [[Category:English television presenters]] [[Category:English radio personalities]] [[Category:English writers]] [[Category:People from Worcester]] [[Category:People educated at the Royal Grammar School Worcester]] [[Category:Alumni of Loughborough University]] [[Category:English auctioneers]]

{{BLP sources|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox artist | name = Ruben Talberg | image = Talberg.jpg | caption = Ruben C. Talberg, 2017 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1964|08|24}} | birth_place = [[Heidelberg]], [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[West Germany]] | nationality = German, Israeli | known_for = Pintura Alchemica | website = {{URL|talberg.art}} }}
[[file:TalbergMuseum.jpg|thumb|Talberg Museum]]
'''Ruben Cornelis Talberg''' (born 24 August 1964 in [[Heidelberg]]) is a [[Germany|German]]-[[Israel]]i [[painting|painter]] and [[photographer]]. Before Talberg turned 40, he invented PINTURA ALCHEMICA in which he inverts the canvasses according to the ancient alchemic principle of "conversio oppositorum".
==Work== R. C. Talberg's oeuvre deals with antagonistic positions such as Nature & Alchemy, Asymmetry & Dynamics or Eros & Thanathos. During the last decade he has intensified his interest for Jewish mysticism and magic. On extensive journeys he creates new serials of photography that in turn shape the base for new artwork cycles. Likewise the surfaces of his artworks contain references to his lyrics, [[West African Vodun|Voodoo]], symbols, grids and codes.
2011 the Talberg Museum was founded in Offenbach am Main. Talberg's works are represented in more than 100 public and private international collections as well as the auction trade.
Talberg lives and works in [[Heidelberg]] and [[Southern France]].<ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.talbergmuseum.net/museum/about | title=Ruben Talberg - Museum - About | publisher= talbergmuseum.net | accessdate= 2012-05-20 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | first= Madeleine| last= Reckmann | url=http://www.fr-online.de/offenbach/kunst-stimme-fuer-juedische-kuenstler,1472856,8537764.html | title=Stimme für jüdische Künstler | date= 2011-06-08 | publisher= [[Frankfurter Rundschau]] | accessdate= 2012-05-20 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | author= Silke Gelhausen-Schüßler | url=http://www.op-online.de/nachrichten/offenbach/wirkungsvolle-eitelkeit-1285106.html | title=Wirkungsvolle Eitelkeit | date= 2011-06-16 | publisher= [[Offenbach-Post]] | accessdate= 2012-05-20 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | first= Simone| last= Weil | url=http://www.op-online.de/nachrichten/offenbach/zeichen-erinnerung-570900.html | title=Ein Zeichen der Erinnerung | date= 2010-12-29 | publisher= [[Offenbach-Post]] | accessdate= 2012-05-20 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | first= Danijel| last= Majic | url=http://www.juedische-allgemeine.de/article/view/id/7659 | title=Ein Zeichen der Erinnerung - Alchemist der Kunst Ruben Talberg und sein Mahnmal-Projekt ''Jakobsleiter'' | date= 2010-06-17 | publisher= [[Jüdische Allgemeine]] | accessdate= 2012-05-20 }}</ref>
== Bibliography==

2010, „INRI“, Talberg Factory
2010, „Jacob's ladder“, Talberg Factory
2010, „Durchkämmung“, Talberg Factory
2010, „Nox“, Talberg Factory
2008, "Damballah", Talberg Factory, {{ISBN|978-3-00-026230-2}}

revision.comment: Unreliable sources
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Tapandegan | pronounce = | native_name = ''Palpitaters'' in [[Persian language|Persian]] | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = Tapandegan logo.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = <!-- use {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | founder = | founding_location = [[Iran]] | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = [[Hacker group]] | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | endowment_year = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }}
The '''Tapandegan''' (''Palpitaters'' in [[Persian language|Persian]]) is an [[Iran]]ian hacker group known for hacking twice the arrival and departure monitors at two major international airports in Iran ([[Mashhad International Airport|Mashhad]] and [[Tabriz International Airport|Tabriz]]) on May 24, 2018 and June 6, 2018 respectively, posting anti-government messages and images, forcing the airports’ authorities to turn off manually those monitors one-by-one.<ref name="ENR">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers Post Protest Messages On Mashad Airport Displays | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''en.radiofarda.com''| date =25 May 2018 | url =https://en.radiofarda.com/a/iran-hackers-post-protest-messages-mashad-airport/29250247.html | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers briefly shut off airport monitors in Iran’s Tabriz | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''seattletimes.com''| date =7 June 2018 | url =https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/hackers-briefly-shut-off-airport-monitors-in-irans-tabriz/ | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers briefly shut off airport monitors in Iran's Tabriz | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''foxnews.com''| date =7 June 2018 | url =http://www.foxnews.com/world/2018/06/07/hackers-briefly-shut-off-airport-monitors-in-irans-tabriz.html | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
The Tapandegan refers to its acts as an act of protest demanding from the Iranian leadership to improve the economy and to stop ignoring the demands of the Iranian people.<ref name="VOA">{{cite news | last =Lipin | first =Michael | title =Hackers Hit Second Iranian Airport with Opposition Message | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''voanews.com''| date =7 June 2018 | url =https://www.voanews.com/a/hackers-hit-second-iranian-airport-opposition-message/4429261.html | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref> News agencies categorized this group’s acts as “a new form of protest in Iran.”<ref name="ENR"/>
==History== The Tapandegan first appeared publicly on May 24, 2018 when they hacked the arrival and departure monitors at [[Mashhad International Airport]] and on June 6, 2018 when they also hacked the arrival and departure monitors at [[Tabriz International Airport]].<ref name="ENR"/> The group posted anti-government messages and images, forcing the airports’ authorities to turn off manually those monitors one-by-one.<ref name="ENR"/> Airport officials in both cities turned off the sign boards for several hours after the hacking and made apologetic public statements.<ref name="ENR"/>
The Iranian authorities confirmed both cyber-attacks shortly after they took place and they were widely reported by the Iranian official press and the international news wires and agencies.<ref name="TIME">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Screens at Iran airport said hacked with anti-regime messages | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''timesofisrael.com''| date =25 May 2018 | url =https://www.timesofisrael.com/screens-at-iran-airport-said-hacked-with-anti-regime-messages/ | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
===Name and alias=== The group’s name is in the [[Persian language]] meaning ''Palpitaters''. Based on the messages they posted on those hacked monitors, the news sources noted that the group supports the national protests of the people in Iran demanding economic improvements.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers post protest messages on Iranian airport monitors | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''azernews.az''| date =7 June 2018 | url =https://www.azernews.az/region/133149.html | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
Iran has seen frequent nationwide protests this year by demonstrators angered by local and national officials and business leaders who they accuse of corruption and oppression. The two anti-government hacks at Iranian airports are the only incidents of their kind since the protests began in late December.<ref>{{cite news | last =Son | first =Do | title =Iranian Airport Electronic Display Screened Protest Messages | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''securityonline.info''| date =29 May 2018 | url =https://securityonline.info/iranian-airport-electronic-display-screened-protest-messages/ | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
==Hacking history== Hacking attacks in Iran have been on the rise recently. In August 2016, Internet security experts warned that hackers have found access to banking and contact details of millions of Iranians by hacking into their Telegram accounts.<ref>{{cite news | last =McGoogan | first =Cara | title =Iranian hackers attack Telegram to find 15 million accounts | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''telegraph.co.uk''| date =3 August 2016 | url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2016/08/03/iranian-hackers-attack-telegram-to-find-15-million-accounts/ | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref> However, it is not yet clear whether this was a genuine warning or an attempt by hardliners in the Iranian government to convince people to leave Telegram and migrate to home-grown messaging services, where the government has easy access to users’ private information and can intercept their communications.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Iran Poised to Block Popular Telegram Messaging App But Lacks Feasible Alternative | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''iranhumanrights.org''| date =5 April 2018 | url =https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2018/04/iran-poised-to-block-popular-telegram-messaging-app-but-lacks-feasible-alternative/ | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =DeGeurin | first =Mack | title =What Iran and Russia’s Telegram Ban Means for Secure Messaging Apps| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''nymag.com''| date =| url =http://nymag.com/selectall/2018/06/the-implications-of-iran-and-russias-attack-on-telegram.html | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
===First hack: The Mashhad International Airport=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Mashhad airport monitor attack.jpg|thumb|Image showing Tapandegan's attack on Mashhad International Airport Monitors on May 24, 2018]] -->
According to [[The Associated Press]]’ report from [[Tehran]], Iran’s official IRNA news agency reported that The Tapandegan “managed to interrupt routine broadcasts on monitors” at the Mashhad International Airport on Thursday evening, May 24, 2018, “replacing them with images of anti-government protests from January [2018]”“for several hours.”<ref name="ENR"/>
Sources report that according to a statement posted by the hackers on the monitors, the group protested to “wasting Iranians lives and financial resources in [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]], [[Lebanon]] and [[Syria]] by the [[Islamic Revolution Guards Corps]] (IRGC).” <ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =The site of the Mashhad airport was hacked by the demonic protest| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''fa.euronews.com''| date =25 May 2018| url =http://fa.euronews.com/2018/05/25/mashhad-international-airport-website-hacked-by-tapandegan| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref> The message posted on sign boards also protested against the IRGC’s presence in [[Syria]], [[Iraq]], and elsewhere in the region.<ref name="ENR"/> The group also hacked the email of Mashhad airport civil aviation head, Mohsen Eidizadeh and sent the news of its hack from his account.<ref>{{cite news | last =Waqas | first = | title =Hackers deface Airport screens in Iran with anti-government messages| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''hackread.com''| date =26 May 2018| url =https://www.hackread.com/hackers-deface-airport-screens-in-iran/| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
[[Mashhad]] is the city where massive anti-government demonstrations started on December 28 and spread to over 100 other Iranians cities. It is a religious city where the holy shrine of the 8th Shiite Imam is located. Local authorities and clerics in the city are among the staunchest hardliners.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Iranian cities hit by anti-government protests| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''bbc.com''| date =29 December 2017| url =https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42512946| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref> The group expressed support for the people of [[Kazeroon]], a city in [[Fars Province]], where people have been demonstrating against the state of months.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers post protest messages on Iranian airport monitors| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''en.presspark.az''| date = | url =http://en.presspark.az/iqtisadiyyat/1699-hackers-post-protest-messages-on-iranian-airport-monitors.html| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
===Second hack: The Tabriz International Airport=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Tabrizpic airport monitor attack.jpg|thumb|Image showing Tapandegan's attack on Tabriz International Airport Monitors on June 6, 2018]] -->
According to The Associated Press’ report from Tehran, Iran’s official IRNA news agency reported that on June 6, 2018, the hackers “have disrupted the arrival and departure monitors in the Tabriz international airport in the country’s northwest.”<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers briefly shut off airport monitors in Iran's Tabriz| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''nydailynews.com''| date =7 June 2018 | url =http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/news/world/hackers-briefly-shut-airport-monitors-iran-tabriz-article-1.4027315| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref> The hackers defaced sign boards in the evening, showing a protest message against “wasting Iranians’ resources" and expressing support for Iranian truckers who have been on strike across Iran for several weeks.<ref>{{cite news | last =ASSOCIATED PRESS | first = | title =Hackers briefly shut off airport monitors in Iran's Tabriz| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''dailymail.co.uk''| date =7 June 2018 | url =http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-5816751/Hackers-briefly-shut-airport-monitors-Irans-Tabriz.html| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
Iranian truck drivers went on strike for more than a week beginning May 22 in several parts of Iran, using social media to mobilize and share images of themselves protesting low wages and rising business costs.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Iran: Truckers surpass 11th day of nationwide strike| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''english.mojahedin.org''| date =1 June 2018 | url =https://english.mojahedin.org/i/iran-truckers-surpass-11th-day-of-nationwide-strike | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Government 'Meets' Striking Truckers Demands To Prevent More Disruption| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''en.radiofarda.com''| date =25 May 2018 | url =https://en.radiofarda.com/a/iran-truckers-strike-disruption/29250450.html | accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
The Iranian state-run site, ''Young Journalists’ Club (YJC)'', “quoted Tabriz Governor Aliyar Rastgoo as saying the incident happened Wednesday at 9:30 p.m. local time.”<ref name="VOA"/> A Tabriz airport official Mostafa Safaei confirmed the day after the cyber-attack that the monitors turned off following the hack and engineers quickly restored the system, and the incident was under investigation.<ref name="VOA"/>
Translation of the message posted by the hackers on the monitors in Persian reads:
''Attention, attention. We, Tapandegan, in another protest action, are currently taking control of the computer systems of this airport. Two weeks ago, in protest against the wastage of the Iranian people’s money and lives by (Iran’s) Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, we took control of the computer systems in Mashhad airport. Today, by voicing our support for Iranian strikers, we are doing the same thing. Until when will this regime deprive people of their rights to have a better livelihood and economic situation?! Until when?! We will not choke off our voices. We will continue these actions. If you support us, take a photo of this and share it''
The Tapandegan assumed responsibility for the hacking in a tweet on June 7.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Tapandegan tweets| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''twitter.com''| date =7 June 2018 | url =https://twitter.com/tapandegan| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers Post Anti-Government Messages on Iranian Airport Signs| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''raytribune.com''| date =8 June 2018 | url =http://raytribune.com/2018/06/08/hackers-post-anti-government-messages-on-iranian-airport-signs/| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref> News of the hacking broke almost immediately on social media as Iranians posted tweets and pictures of the incident. However, the posts came under pseudonyms as users inside Iran fear a heavy-handed clampdown by the government.<ref name="TIME"/>
Sources report that The Tapandegan sent an email to Iranian journalists saying, “Two weeks ago, we took over the computer systems of Mashhad Airport in support of the national protests. We protested against wasting Iranian lives and assets by IRGC [The Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]. And, today, we support the truck drivers, the bazar, and the strikers”.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Hackers post protest messages on Iranian airport monitors| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''en.trend.az''| date =7 June 2018 | url =https://en.trend.az/iran/politics/2914159.html| accessdate =26 June 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[2017–18 Iranian protests]] * [[2018 Dervish protests]] * [[2018 Khuzestan protests]] * [[Iranian Cyber Army]] * [[Cyberwarfare in Iran]] * [[Mashhad International Airport]] * [[Tabriz International Airport]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
'''Tony Shearer''' (born '''Fred Anthony Shearer''' October 27, 1926, [[Colorado]], d. May 2002) was an American [[Mayanism]] proponent and [[New Age]] author who wrote books contributing to the modern popularization of syncretic beliefs in which elements of [[Maya calendar|Maya calendrics]] are highlighted in the supposed significance of dates in [[2012 doomsday prediction|December 2012 A.D.]], as well as [[Harmonic Convergence|August 1987 A.D.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TmZEfOe1OCwC&pg=PA121&dq=tony+shearer&lr=#v=onepage&q=tony+shearer&f=false|title=The Mystery of 2012: Predictions, Prophecies & Possibilities|first1=Sounds True|last1=(Firm)|first2=Gregg|last2=Braden|date=17 August 2017|publisher=Sounds True|accessdate=17 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>.
Shearer stated in the preface to his 1971 book that he withdrew from a promising career in conventional [[broadcast journalism]] in the 1960s in order to investigate the [[meaning of life]], leading him to research and experience beliefs and practices of ancient and modern [[Mesoamerican]]s. He then published a work titled "Quetzalcoatl: Lord of the Dawn" in June 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0911010742|title=Lord of the Dawn: Quetzalcoatl|first=Tony|last=Shearer|date=1 June 1971|publisher=Naturegraph Pub|accessdate=17 August 2017|via=Amazon}}</ref> The work was republished with the text and illustrations unchanged in 1995, titled "Quetzalcoatl: Lord of the Dawn and the Tree of Life".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0879612401|title=Lord of the Dawn: Quetzalcoatl and the Tree of Life|first=Tony|last=Shearer|date=1 March 1995|publisher=Naturegraph Pub|accessdate=17 August 2017|via=Amazon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hamsa|first1=Chuck|title=The Praying Flute|url=http://www.naturegraph.com/indian/in-gen/Praying_.html|publisher=Naturegraph|accessdate=15 August 2017|date=September 2005|quote=Shearer died in May of 2002 at 75 years of age.}}</ref>
==Books== *''Quetzalcoatl, Lord of the Dawn'', published 1971, 1995 *''Beneath the Moon and Under the Sun: A Poetic Reappraisal of the Sacred Calendar and the Prophecies of Ancient Mexico'', 1975 *''The Praying Flute: Song of the Earth Mother: A Bald Mountain Story'' (Children's Book) published 1975, 1988, 1991, 2004 *''The Story as Told'', co-authored with Jalil Mahmoudi, Massood Mahmoudi *''The Sacred Calendar of Quetzalcoatl'', 1976 *''Spirit Song'',1981. *''Boy and Tree and Poetic Myth'', 1993.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
*[http://www.diagnosis2012.co.uk/harm.htm How did Tony Shearer calculate Harmonic Convergence?] *[[Native American flute]] manufacturer pays tribute to [https://web.archive.org/web/20090605023340/http://aoflutes.com/abtartst2.htm "Lakota artist, storyteller, and author Tony Shearer."]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shearer, Tony}} [[Category:New Age writers]] [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]]

revision.text:
{{Nerva–Antonine dynasty |image=[[File:Ulpia Marciana Met 20.200 n02.jpg|250px]] |caption=Portrait bust of Ulpia Marciana |birth=August 48 AD|death=112}} '''Ulpia Marciana''' (August 48 – 112) was the beloved elder sister of [[Roman Emperor]] [[Trajan]]. She was the eldest child born to Roman woman [[Marcia (mother of Trajan)|Marcia]] and the [[Hispania|Spanish Roman]] senator [[Marcus Ulpius Traianus (senator)|Marcus Ulpius Traianus]]. Her second name ''Marciana'' she inherited from her mother’s paternal ancestors. Her birthplace is unknown.
Marciana married [[Gaius Salonius Matidius Patruinus]]. Patruinus was a wealthy man, who served as a [[praetor]] and later became a senator. He originally came from Vicetia (modern [[Vicenza]] in northern [[Italy]]). She bore Patruinus a daughter and only child [[Salonina Matidia]], who was born on July 4, 68. Patruinus died in 78 and Marciana never remarried. After Patruinus’ death, Marciana and Matidia went to live with Trajan and his wife.
After 105, her brother awarded her with the title of [[Augusta (honorific)|Augusta]]. She was the first sister of a Roman Emperor to receive this title. Marciana did not accept this at first, but her sister-in-law, the Empress [[Pompeia Plotina]], insisted that she take the title. She thus became part of the official imperial iconography and her statue was placed together with Trajan's and Plotina's over the [[Arch of Trajan (Ancona)|Arches of Trajan]] in [[Ancona]]. Marciana was very close to Trajan and Plotina.
[[Image:Marciana Coin.jpg|thumb|left|Marciana on a sestertius of Trajan]] Marciana would often travel with her brother and assist him in decision making. Throughout the Roman Empire, Marciana was honored with monuments and inscriptions in her name. There are two towns that Trajan founded in her honor in the [[Roman Empire]]. The first town was called ''Colonia Marciana Ulpia Traiana Thamugadi'' (modern [[Timgad]], [[Algeria]]) and was founded around 100. This town was also named after the late parents of Marciana and Trajan. The other town was founded in 106 and was called [[Marcianopolis]] (which is now a part of modern [[Devnya]], [[Bulgaria]]). Marciana died between 112 and 114 and was [[Imperial cult (ancient Rome)|deified by the Senate]] at Trajan's behest.<ref>E. J. Bickerman, "Diva Augusta Marciana," ''The Journal of Philology'' 95.4 (Winter, 1974): 362-376.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livius.org/person/ulpia-marciana/ |title=Ulpia Marciana |website=livius.org |accessdate=11 January 2015 }}</ref>
Through her daughter [[Salonina Matidia]]'s third marriage, Marciana was the great-great-great grandmother of future emperor [[Marcus Aurelius]]. {{clear left}} {{Nerva-Antonine family tree}}
==See also== * [[Ulpia (gens)]]
==References== {{commons category}} <references/>
